Currently we maintain websites in the languages of the principal countries where we operate. Additionally, in September 2016, we acquired two online pure players, Happyview.fr and Malentille.com. We have incorporated the activities of Happyview.fr into our French Afflelou website. Malentille.com continues to serve customers on its own platform with back-end integration with the Group’s online activities. Our principal activity is to act as a franchisor, licensing the use of our brand to franchisees and providing them with the right to trade under our brand and implement our value proposition through our ----- commercial offers. Our directly-owned stores support our principal franchisor activity by (i) serving as flagship locations in and around Paris and other key strategic locations and large urban areas; (ii) helping to test new concepts; (iii) facilitating store network management; and (iv) generating high purchase volumes, which facilitates our negotiations with suppliers. Our services as a franchisor are aimed at helping franchisees grow their sales by fostering a strong brand image, driving customers to our stores through the design and promotion of our commercial offers and facilitating franchisee operations via a number of support services. Our scale and expertise yield tangible benefits to our franchisees, allowing us to offer (i) commercial support and innovation through new commercial offers and through high-impact national and local communication campaigns that create high brand awareness; (ii) access to central listing and purchasing unit services that lower costs for our franchisees; (iii) dedicated services that enhance store attractiveness, including assistance with location selection and store design; (iv) training programs designed to enhance sales performance; and (v) other general support functions, including legal, human resources and recruiting assistance, as well as assistance with joining care networks in France. Our franchise model also offers tangible benefits to our suppliers by giving them access to our global network of stores. We also provide suppliers with distribution services, including a central listing and payment unit that allows suppliers to list and offer their products to our franchisees, while offering the benefit of having a single counterparty for commercial negotiations and payments. We also support suppliers by actively promoting their innovative products to our franchisees, as well as through sales in our directly-owned stores. Our franchise model combines: (i) revenue based on network sales of our franchisees (27.4% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023), (ii) revenue based on purchases (42.2% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023) and (iii) revenue generated by sales to end-customers in our directly-owned stores and through our websites (30.4% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023). Revenue based on network sales includes in particular: entry fees, franchise fees and communication fees, as well as other fees charged for services that we provide to our franchisees. Revenue based on purchases includes in particular: trading as well as central listing and payment unit (which are charged to our listed suppliers) and licensing fees and revenue from sales of our exclusive products. Revenue generated by our directly-owned stores mainly includes sales made directly to endcustomers in those directly-owned stores, as well as through our websites. This model not only provides us with revenue diversification but also increases our Adjusted EBITDA by increasing our network sales at limited fixed costs when opening new franchisee stores. This results in greater economies of scale and improved operating leverage and profitability. Our main costs are related to the supply and production of products that we sell under our own brands or for which we have a license. For our exclusive frames, Okia, a company based in China, has long been our favored intermediary. Okia is not a manufacturer but sources its products from a network of independent factories in Asia and allows the Group to benefit from optimal production conditions through this unique commercial relationship.

Subsubsection Title: We operate in resilient and predictable largely non-discretionary health-care related markets that benefit from established structural growth dynamics
Subsubsection Text: We operate in health-care related markets that benefit from established structural growth dynamics, namely: (i) an aging population and increased focus on wellness, (ii) an accrued use of screens and earphones, (iii) a stable replacement cycle for non-discretionary products, (iv) an under-equipment of the population in hearing aids and (v) a favorable regulatory and reimbursement framework, like in France, which is expected to drive increased demand for more products such as prescription glasses and hearing aids in the coming years. Our markets, different from traditional retail markets, are largely ----- non-discretionary and health-related, and therefore are more stable and predictable because as the aging population continues to grow so does the demand for our products. Consumers replace their glasses, contact lenses and hearing aids multiple times over their lifetimes and for a variety reasons, including for health reasons, such as changes in vision and hearing levels, as well as due to loss, damage, improved technology and changing fashion trends and consumer preferences. In addition, these factors drive stable replacement cycles. For example, in France, the average replacement cycle from 2015 to 2021 was estimated to be 2.8 years, which replacement cycle remained stable for the last ten years according to a report prepared by Advancy in 2022. In Spain, the average replacement cycle from 2015 to 2021 was estimated to be 4.2 years, according to the same report. As discussed further below in “—We sell essential health-related products, most of which _represent non-discretionary spending by our customers, making our business resilient and predictable”,_ most of our products are purchased because a customer has a health-related need, which distinguishes these products from traditional retail and consumer goods and creates relative resilience and predictability in our markets. The market for optical and hearing aid products in our core markets is large. These markets are also expanding as their populations age. According to INSEE, the French national statistics institute and INE, the Spanish national statistics institute, 46.9% and 50.5% of the French and Spanish populations, respectively, were 45 or older in 2023. Because eye and ear conditions, such as farsightedness and age-related hearing loss, usually develop after the ages of 40 and 55, respectively, and generally become more common and serious with age, the number of potential customers should increase as a consequence of the aging of the population in the countries in which we operate, with similar tailwinds benefitting both optical products and hearing aids. The optical product and hearing aid markets are also supported by other positive structural demographic trends and other growth levers, including changing lifestyles, technological improvements and product penetration dynamics. For example, we believe that evolving technology for corrective lenses and hearing aids, particularly improvements in multi-focal lenses and increasingly small microphones leading to smaller hearing aids, as well as shifting customer preferences as seen in increasing demand for custom lenses, leads consumers to replace old equipment. Penetration in the hearing aid segment is also expected to increase given the overall widespread presence of connected wireless headphones, limiting the negative preconceived image of hearing aid devices. In addition, there is greater demand for customized lenses or “progressive lenses”, which has led to increased average basket size, as well as “wellness” lenses such as blue light lenses. Increased diversified and complex needs have contributed to additional revenue. The below chart shows the increase in the proportion of progressive lenses purchased from 2012 to 2023 in France and Spain. _Source: GfK._ The French optical products market grew by a CAGR of 2.7% from 2019 to 2023, and the Spanish optical products market grew by a CAGR of 2.4% from 2019 to 2023, in each case according to GfK. The French hearing aid market has grown by a CAGR of 10.5% from 2019 to 2023, according to Xerfi ----- estimates. The chart below shows the evolution of the optical markets in France and Spain for the calendar years presented. _Source: GfK Optical market of France and Spain._ We expect to see accelerated growth in the hearing aid market, particularly in France, since the implementation of _100% Santé. Historically, hearing aids were an under-penetrated product class in our markets where in 2022 only approximately 46.0% of people in France who required hearing aids were equipped with them according to EuroTrak. This was largely due to the fact that hearing aids were prohibitively expensive, which led to patients delaying equipping themselves with such devices. In addition, historically, the public lacked general awareness of the effectiveness of the use of hearing aids. We expect to see significant long-term growth in the hearing aid market in France resulting from the partial correction of this historical under-penetration and further driven by the regulatory changes relating to RAC Zéro (the zero-cost to consumer offer under French regulation for hearing aids that went into effect in January 2021), which makes hearing aids significantly more affordable. We believe that many people who require hearing aids have delayed purchasing them because of the costs, especially prior to the implementation of the RAC Zéro scheme. We have benefited and continue to expect to benefit from a progressive equipment penetration in hearing aid sales as awareness of the effectiveness of hearing aids and knowledge of more discreet models of hearing aids spreads, and the public becomes more aware of the RAC Zéro changes and, in the long-term, we expect to benefit from RAC Zéro being replaced by individuals being able to purchase hearing aids through the French health-care system. The chart below shows the expected increase in adoption of the use of hearing aids in France for those with hearing loss from 2012 to 2027. _Sources: EuroTrak and Les Echos._ Hearing loss is an increasingly common and irreversible phenomenon that comes with aging and which is amplified by certain lifestyle choices, such as living in noisy environments or frequent use of headphones. The prevalence of hearing loss, which is estimated to impact around 10.0% of the population, according to a 2022 EuroTrak study, is positively correlated with the increasing population of people aged 65 and older, as well as with increasing levels of noise pollution. It is estimated that more than a quarter of the population of people aged 65 and over have some degree of hearing loss. ----- The changes brought by 100% Santé significantly increased the use of hearing aids in 2021, and as the chart above illustrates, penetration is expected to increase to 50.0% by 2027, representing an increase in our addressable market.

Subsubsection Title: We sell essential health-related products, most of which represent non-discretionary spending by our customers and are underpinned by a supportive regulatory environment, making our business stable, predictable and well positioned to weather macroeconomic headwinds
Subsubsection Text: The health-related nature of our products makes them largely non-discretionary purchases that may, at best, be sometimes delayed but rarely deferred completely. Most of our products are purchased because a customer has a health-related need. For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, 96.0% of network sales were generated by sales of products providing corrective vision or hearing, namely: prescription glasses (82.0%), hearing aids (8.0%), contact lenses (6.0%), and only 4.0% of network sales were generated by sales of items such as sunglasses and accessories which are not generally bought for a health-related needs. According to Gallileo, in 2024 85.0% of customers indicated their reason for purchasing new glasses was due to a need compared to 15.0% who indicated it was based on personal, non-health-related preference, at levels comparable with previous years. As the population continues to age, we expect customers to continue to purchase our products for health-related needs, which provides our business with stability, predictability and resilience. In addition, we have benefited and will continue to benefit from the supportive regulatory environment, making the purchase of healthcare related products, such as glasses and hearing aids, more accessible. For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, 98.0% of the French population had health insurance to cover optical expenses as shown below.

Subsection Title: Health Insurance Covering Optical Expenses in France
Subsubsection Text: _Sources: Company information, Galileo 2024 and Advancy report._ In the year ended July 31, 2023, approximately 95.0% of optical expenses were not related to public spending or policies, as shown below, as the insurance coverage mostly corresponds to private health insurance.

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Title: We are a leading European franchisor, with a proven business model that is founded on long-standing and supportive relationships with franchisees and is positioned at the heart of the value chain
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading franchisor in the European optical product and hearing aid markets, with over 40 years of experience partnering with our franchisees in our core domestic markets (France and Spain) as well countries that border our core markets (Belgium, Luxembourg, Switzerland and Portugal) and satellite markets in the Middle East, Africa, and South America, where we continue to grow strategically. Our franchise business is our core activity and in terms of revenue and number of stores, we are the leading retail chain franchise network in France and a leading franchisor in continental Europe. As of July 31, 2023, our store network included 1,418 stores and generated network sales of €876.1 million in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. The average length of our relationship for more than 50.0% of our total number of franchisees is ten years, and over 23 years for 17.0% of our total number of franchisees. Approximately 96.0% of our total number of franchisees in France remain year over year. We have developed our successful franchise model, which has particular, historical strength in the optical product sector, by combining the power of our brands with commercial innovations and close relationships with franchisees and suppliers. We believe this model sets us apart from our competitors. ----- Since 2003, we have successfully taken this differentiated operating model, which we have developed and refined with decades of experience in our core geographical and product markets, and rolled it out to other countries, as seen by our success in building our networks in Belgium, Switzerland and Luxembourg, in particular. We have historically had good results in rolling this model out in countries with French-speaking populations but believe this model also works well in non-French speaking countries and regions, as shown by the strength of our network in Spain. Since 2011 (except for 2013 to 2016, during which period the ALAIN AFFLELOU hearing aid business in France was operated by our shareholders outside of the Group), we have rolled this model out in the hearing aid markets in France, Spain and Switzerland, which works well across complementary product groups as well as across strategically-selected geographies as demonstrated by the graphs below. (1) Excluding Optical Discount. We operate the largest French optical product franchise network in terms of both revenue and number of stores and ALAIN AFFLELOU is the third-largest optical business, with a 9.0% market share in 2023 (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales) a fragmented market that has historically included many independent retailers. In addition to our historical French market, we have a large and well-developed network in Spain, our second core domestic market, where we had 363 stores as of July 31, 2023. In 2019, we operated the largest optical product franchise network in Spain in terms of number of stores and were the fifth largest optical retail chain, with a 7.0% market share (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales) (according to Xerfi). In the hearing aid market, ALAIN AFFLELOU Acousticien has grown faster than the market average (with a CAGR of 18.0%, from the fiscal year ended July 31, 2015 to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 compared to the market rate of approximately 9.0% over the period from the calendar years 2015 to 2023, as estimated by Xerfi) and held an approximately 3.0% market share in France in 2023 (according to Xerfi). Our hearing aid network in Spain has also grown rapidly in recent years, from 36 points of sale as of July 31, 2019 to 152 points of sale as of April 30, 2024. We believe we currently hold a 2.0% ----- market share in Spain (as estimated by Sra.Modne). We operate Alain Afflelou Acousticien with fundamentally the same sustainable business model as ALAIN AFFLELOU, including how contributions and fees are paid from franchisees. As a result, we believe that, over the long-term, profit levels at Alain Afflelou Acousticien will eventually converge with and stabilize at levels comparable to ALAIN AFFLELOU. Our business model is mature and well-developed, with a controlled fixed cost base such that, when sales increase, we benefit from economies of scale that drive higher margins. In addition, our franchise model combines multiple sources of revenue from both franchisees (comprising franchise fees (entry fees and royalty fees) and communication fees, as well as wholesale activity revenue from the sale of exclusive own-branded products and central purchasing unit revenue) and suppliers (comprising central listing and payment fees and license royalties). This approach provides us with revenue diversification and attractive margins, as demonstrated by our 13.1% Adjusted EBITDA margin as a percentage of network sales for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. We also leverage our directly-owned store network to manage, support and develop our franchise business. Our directly-owned stores support our principal franchisor activity by serving as flagship locations in and around Paris and other key strategic locations, helping to test new concepts, facilitating store network management and supporting negotiation with suppliers, through significant supply volumes. The success of our franchisee-centered business model is demonstrated by the over-performance of our franchisees compared to the wider market. Average revenue per store for ALAIN AFFLELOU in France for the 2021 calendar year was €0.9 million (including VAT), which is approximately 1.5 times the retail market average (and approximately 3.3 times the independent and smaller marketing group retailer store in 2021), and our average revenue per store in Spain for the calendar year ended 2019 was €0.4 million, which was approximately 2.1 times the retail market average in that year (and approximately 4.8 times the independent and smaller market group retailer store average in 2019). The over-performance of our franchisees has resulted in higher network sales growth rates in France and Spain as shown below. _Sources: Company Information, Xerfi and GfK._ The success of our business model is founded on our place at the center of the relationships among our suppliers, franchisees and customers, which brings value to each of these groups. For example, our scale and expertise generates multiple synergies and offers tangible benefits to our franchisees. Moreover, we provide our franchisees with commercial support and innovation through new commercial offers, including high-impact national and local advertising campaigns that create high brand awareness, access to central purchasing unit services that lower their costs, dedicated services that enhance store attractiveness (including assistance with location selection and store design), training programs designed to enhance sales performance and other general support functions, including human resources, recruiting assistance and financing assistance. Our signature products are another key value differentiator for our franchisees, generating customer interest, with affordable products that offer good margins, which benefit our franchisees as well as us. We support our franchisees with long-term commitments to their success, as demonstrated by how we help our franchisees adapt to change, such as through our Adelante financial support program (which we believe is a differentiator that few of our competitors are able to match), our Elite program (which is designed to assist franchisees that are underperforming), assistance with store refurbishments and support for adding hearing aid corners that make optical stores more attractive. As of July 31, 2023, ----- approximately 140 of our stores in Spain and France have benefitted from our Adelante financial support program. We are also there to help our franchisees face exceptional challenges. Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, we supported our franchisees in a variety of ways, including offering solutions that allowed them to defer an aggregate of €30 million in franchisee payables, in addition to €15 million of bank loans that we guaranteed. These have all been repaid by our franchisees and no amounts remained outstanding under these advances as at July 31, 2023. Our franchise model also offers tangible benefits to our suppliers by giving them access to our large store network. We provide suppliers with distribution services, such as access to our central listing and payment unit that allows suppliers to list and offer their products to our large network of franchisees. We also centralize payments from our networks to obtain optimal terms and facilitate credit management, to the benefit of these suppliers. We further support suppliers by jointly developing and actively promoting their innovative products to our franchisees, as well as through sales in our directly-owned stores. We believe that this value-added approach creates stable and reliable relationships with our suppliers, which in turn drives cost-efficiency for us and makes us a more attractive partner to our franchisees.

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Title: We are a deeply-entrenched optical and hearing aid leader that benefits from high brand awareness
Subsubsection Text: We are a well-known and trusted leader in the optical and hearing aid markets. We are currently the third-largest market participant in France, with 9.0% of market share (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales), and the fifth-largest market participant in Spain, with 7.0% of market share (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales) according to Xerfi. ALAIN AFFLELOU is positioned as a generalist optical and hearing aid retailer and includes “Alain Afflelou optical” and the “Alain Afflelou Acousticien” hearing aid business, which are now promoted together as “Alain Afflelou opticien & acousticien”. ALAIN AFFLELOU benefits from high brand awareness across our main geographies, consistently ranking number one in spontaneous or assisted awareness in France (as measured by Arcane, Galileo and Opinionway), number two in Spain (as measured by Punto de Fuga), and number two in the French-speaking regions of Belgium (as measured by CSA). We believe that we are well-positioned to maintain this market-leading brand awareness as these markets grow and evolve. We regularly receive awards for our offerings and our customer service. We have also won a number of industry awards in both France and Spain, such as optical customer service provider of the year by the Elu service client de l’année (ESCDA) market survey, conducted by Viseo Customer Insights, in France for eight years in a row (2017 to 2024), best French optical franchise according to “Le Figaro _2024 Client Satisfaction Survey”, “Óptica del año” by Inma Stratmarketing for best optician in Spain in_ 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018, “best franchise in shopping centre” by the Asociación Española de Centros _Comerciales in 2018 and “foreign franchise with the best implantation in the Spanish market” by the Asociación Española de Franquicias in 2018, as well as for our television and video advertisements_ which customers easily recall. Some of our franchisees also won the award of best hearing aid and optical franchisee in France in 2018 and 2020 by the _Fédération des Réseaux Européens de _Partenariats et de Franchise (IREF)._ We have a long history of developing successful marketing and branding concepts, offers and products, such as Tchin Tchin (second pair of glasses for €1, launched in 1999), NextYear (payment in installments over 12 to 24 months, launched in 2009), Magic (innovative own branded frames with magnetic clips, launched in 2017), H2O (a model of exclusive sunglasses made from five bottles of recycled plastic recovered from the ocean, introduced in 2020) and more recently, CARACTERES, a middle-high range of fashion frames and sunglasses, which we believe help us grow and maintain our high levels of brand awareness, keeping our brand fresh and top of mind with new and potential customers. Where appropriate, we sometimes expand a brand concept across our product offerings, such as the introduction of Tchin Tchin to our hearing aid business in 2019 and the current implementation of tele-audiology, to complement the implementation of teleophthalmology in 2022. Finally, we regularly rank number one in the sector for innovative banner (as determined by Gallileo in ----- customer surveys from 2019 to 2024), and we held this ranking over the last two years as a result of the launch of our teleophthalmology solution in France. Our innovative banner is regularly recognized in the industry. For example, in November 2023, our teleophthalmology solution was awarded the “Innovative Retailer” Gold Medal at the 10th Nuit du Commerce Connecté.

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Title: Our business model is data-driven, flexible and tailored to our customers’ needs
Subsubsection Text: We leverage our historical strength in the French and Spanish optical product markets and employ a generalist concept that operates not only in city centers but also in a growing number of stores in shopping centers and in retail parks to diversify our offering to respond to changing dynamics in our markets. To that end, we have developed (i) a multi-channel concept that is supported by the execution of a digital transformation plan that helps us tailor our customers’ experiences to their needs and preferences, while expanding our digital presence with “click-and-mortar” functionality, (ii) multiple store formats that respond to varied customer preferences while actively managing our store networks to adapt to evolutions in our markets and (iii) a complementary hearing aid business, grounded in standalone franchised stores as well as value-additive hearing aid corners within existing optical stores. We believe that this approach and these developments help us better serve our customers and our franchisees and in turn makes us an attractive partner for our suppliers. In recent years, we have invested deeply in digital transformation focused on developing forward-thinking, multi-format and fully-integrated customer relationship management (“CRM”) tools, which provide us and our franchisees with valuable data that allow us to better understand our customers and tailor our offerings to meet and anticipate their needs. We believe we are currently well-equipped to gather and analyze data from our franchisees, websites and directly-owned stores. On a daily basis, most of our franchisees provide us with sell-out data, which we use to understand customer behavior and to adjust our purchases based on evolutions in customer preferences. We believe that we are well-positioned to pivot from the investment phase of our digital transformation and CRM plan to a growth phase that puts this data to work for us and for our franchisees. We are also increasingly promoting the use of online bookings for in-store appointments, which reduces wait times, improves store efficiency and also helps to drive traffic into stores, with significant customer uptake on this value-added service in past year. This tool helps us to track and forecast flows in our business and to re-direct traffic as needed, creating more predictability for our stores and letting us offer a more personal experience to our customers. We have a presence in the online market for optical products, primarily for contact lenses. In addition, we have developed know-how for our existing online platform over the last several years. For example, we are present on social media (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Instagram, Pinterest, YouTube and TikTok) and have developed apps and webtools that our customers can use to interact with our product offering, for example allowing them to book appointments, track their contact lens replacement cycle, to locate the nearest store or to virtually try on our frames. We have developed a comprehensive approach for our digital business consistent with our historical marketing positioning, in order to position ourselves as a leader, taking into account the relatively low e-commerce penetration in our sector. In parallel, we actively manage our store networks and store formats, using our expertise to identify changes in the market and to adapt our store locations, formats and sizes to meet demand and emerging opportunities, including through strategic relocations, adjustments to store sizes in city centers and development of larger store formats outside city centers. In recent years, a growing share of our franchised stores have been located in shopping centers and retail parks. We are optimistic that we will continue to be able to adapt our networks to meet customer demand going forward. As a result of the active management of our store network, the distribution of our stores between city centers, shopping centers and retail parks as of July 31, 2023 was 43.3%, 30.0% and 26.7%, respectively, compared to 54.2%, 32.1% and 13.8%, respectively, as of July 31, 2013. We are combining our historical optical business with a complementary hearing aid offering that responds to anticipated growth in demand supported by a new, supportive healthcare framework in France. ----- Since 2011 (except for 2013 to 2016, during which period the Alain Afflelou hearing aid business in France was operated by our shareholders outside of the Group), we have pursued a combined strategy through the creation of our complementary Alain Afflelou Acousticien business in the French and Spanish hearing aid markets. We have modelled the Alain Afflelou Acousticien strategy on our successful approach in the French and Spanish optical product markets, capitalizing on key success factors, such as our experience as a large franchisor, our strong brand awareness, our disruptive, price-focused approach and our history of commercial innovation, and leveraging our significant store network to develop cross-selling opportunities and synergies, such as through the opening of hearing aid corners within optical stores, and to expand our footprint in a cost efficient manner. We believe the _100% Santé changes in France have driven increased penetration in the currently underpenetrated_ French hearing aid market, where 46.0% of people had hearing impairments in 2022 (compared to less than 40.0% in Spain) according to Eurotrak, as these products are now significantly more affordable for those who need them but are not yet equipped or those who may need to replace their existing hearing aids. We believe our well-established business is poised to capture growth in this market, especially through the expansion of corners inside our tier-one locations in our optical network, in which we believe there is significant potential in the mid- to long-term.

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Title: We have a robust financial track record with a high EBITDA to cash conversion ratio and fast- paced deleveraging as a result of an attractive margin profile and asset-light model
Subsubsection Text: Our business model, based on our highly-developed franchise business and asset-light, controlled fixed cost base that requires limited working capital and capital expenditure, drives our stable, healthy and predictable margins and cash generation. Our Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of network sales was consistently above 12.0% from the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 and in the twelve-month period ended April 30, 2024, in each case excluding Optical Discount. Over the same period, our free cash flow was consistently above 60.0%. Such free cash flow generation has given us the flexibility to apply free cash generated from operations to a variety of uses, including debt service and debt reduction. See “—Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Measures—Group Profitability Measurements—Adjusted EBITDA Pre-IFRS 16”._ The tables below show the evolution of our Adjusted EBITDA margin as a percentage of network sales and cash flow conversion ratio from the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 through the twelve months ended April 30, 2024. ----- _Source: Company Information._ (1) Excluding Optical Discount. (2) Reported fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 Adjusted EBITDA (including Optical Discount) was €100.7 million and reported fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 Adjusted EBITDA on network sales (including Optical Discount) was 11.9%. (3) Free cash flow conversion is defined as Adjusted EBITDA Pre-IFRS 16 minus (i) net capital expenditure and (ii) income tax paid) divided by Adjusted EBITDA Pre-IFRS 16. (4) Fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 figures include Optical Discount perimeter. As a franchisor, we have built an asset-light model that requires limited capital expenditure to expand our networks, as almost all capital expenditures for the franchised stores in our networks are borne by our franchisees, who are responsible for their own store investments. From time to time, we support the expansion of the network through our Adelante program, whereby we lend funds, which generally do not exceed 25.0% of the total project, to our franchisees. We only bear the investment costs for our limited network of directly-owned stores, which also helps us keep our capital expenditure needs relatively low. These needs generally correspond to the maintenance of our directly-owned stores perimeter and the purchasing and selling of directly-owned stores on behalf of franchisors. Our financial performance is also bolstered by strong network sales at our ALAIN AFFLELOU network, which grew from €807.0 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to €876.1 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. Our store count and network sales have benefited from the reputation of our franchise network, which encourages franchisees to open new stores and expand our store network. This growth was evidenced by the increase of our Adjusted EBITDA margins as a percentage of network sales to 12.0% for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2022 and 2023 (on a post-IFRS 16 basis). We believe that strong network sales performance is a lever that can drive bottom-line improvement, particularly in ----- our hearing aids business and in our networks in countries that border our core markets, where we believe there is room to grow off the back of economies of scale driven by our franchise model and fixed cost base, as network sales growth generally requires limited expenses. Additionally, we have historically achieved strong cash flow generation and attractive free cash flow conversion dynamics, with a 69.4% free cash flow conversion rate for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, as a result of our limited capital expenditure needs. We also believe there are significant profitability upside opportunities from operating leverage within our developing businesses, such as our hearing aids business and our operations in countries that border our core markets. We also have limited working capital requirements, supported by the soundness of our network and quality of their payments. As a consequence, we believe the evolution of working capital, in the normal course of our business, is limited and mostly depends on seasonality of expenses such as communication or own exclusive products. For example as noted above, we provided financial assistance to our franchisees to help them weather the COVID-19 pandemic, which amounts were rapidly repaid by our franchisees. No amounts remained outstanding under these advances as from July 31, 2023. Finally, from time to time, we invest in innovation projects on behalf of the whole network, with a goal to accelerate the deployment of our innovation, like we did with teleophthalmology, or to foster the digital transformation. As a consequence, we successfully improved our cash and cash equivalents to €75.2 million as of July 31, 2023 (compared to €55.4 million as of July 31, 2022) and €105.0 million as of April 30, 2024. These factors contribute to a robust record of cash generation, strong free cash flow, free cash flow conversion and profitability. Our profitability combined with strong cash flow generation and limited capital expenditures needs and working capital requirements have allowed us to apply free cash flow to reduce our leverage: the ratio of our total net debt (post-IFRS 16) to our Adjusted EBITDA decreased from 5.2x as of July 31, 2021 to 4.8x as of July 31, 2023. We successfully refinanced our Group in 2021 for a total amount of €485 million, and issued additional notes for €50 million in 2022. In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, we have further reduced our leverage from 5.2x as of July 31, 2022 to 4.8x as of July 31, 2023 and 4.4x as of April 30, 2024. For more information on our total net debt (post-IFRS 16) to our Adjusted EBITDA, see “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information—Other Financial _Information”._

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Title: We are led by an experienced management team with a proven track record
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from the experience and industry know-how of our senior management team. Our new CEO, Anthony Afflelou, appointed in June 2022, benefits from the support of his family and has a longstanding management team. Collectively, the members of our management committee have years of experience with the Group, and most have worked together as a team for many years and benefit from significant experience in the retail, optical and hearing aid industries, in addition to having a thorough understanding of the regulatory dynamics in the jurisdictions where we operate. The breadth of the experience of the management team, resulting in a 360 vision for the Group, constitutes a key driver of our strong performance. This longevity of our management committee members underscores our strength, bringing seasoned expertise and commitment to our vision. Our management team has delivered significant operational improvements in recent years and achieved consistent Adjusted EBITDA growth in recent years despite evolving market conditions.

Subsection Title: Percentage of Optical Expenses Reimbursed in France
Subsubsection Text: ----- _Sources: Company information, Galileo 2024 and Advancy Report._ The COVID-19 pandemic and the recent inflationary period demonstrated strong indications of our resilience and ability to weather macroeconomic headwinds. According to GfK, the total optical market size in France was €7.4 billion in 2023 (excluding sales recorded outside of metropolitan France), compared to €6.7 billion in 2019 before the COVID-19 pandemic, and €5.9 billion in 2020 at the height of COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that even when certain of our stores closed due to COVID-19-related restrictions, the net result was that many purchases were either merely redirected to other stores in our network, rather than not being made or being deferred over the long-term, or were merely delayed until our stores reopened. As evidence of the latter, we observed a “catchup” effect whereby, when our stores reopened after COVID-19-related closures, we often saw customers making purchases that they had been planning or waiting to make during such closures. Additionally, measures aimed at curbing the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic evolved favorably for our industry in our core geographies. For example, during the second confinement in France, which began in November 2020, the sale of optical and hearing aid products was deemed an “essential” service, in recognition of the non-discretionary healthcare needs addressed by these items, which generally allowed our stores to remain open (where not otherwise limited by other restrictions that are not specific to the optical and hearing aid sectors, such as those in place for large shopping centers in France). This represented a significantly improved operating environment for our industry compared to the more restrictive and exceptional confinement measures imposed in France during the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic in the spring of 2020, when our stores were generally limited to providing “emergency” services.

Subsubsection Title: Increase our franchise network footprint in our domestic markets
Subsubsection Text: We intend to further develop our network through new franchised store openings in our domestic markets (France and Spain) within the ALAIN AFFLELOU business. We believe that there is still headroom to expand our Alain Afflelou network in France by more than 150 points of sale and 75 points of sale in Spain. We also believe we will be in a position to seize opportunities, both in terms of white space in the retail space that has emerged since the COVID-19 pandemic and due to more independent opticians being willing to join a larger banner. In past years, we have offered strong support to franchisees in order to expand our network, such as our Adelante program in France and Spain, which facilitates the opening and purchase of optical stores for new franchisees. We have also started to strengthen our communication toward professional and training programs for young opticians in order to attract new candidates. We also believe there are also several continued avenues for network optimization, including more actively managing our network and redeploying stores in order to capture more consumer traffic.

Subsubsection Title: Accelerate further expansion in hearing aid products in all existing markets
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue our rapid expansion into the hearing aid market, with the aim of becoming a reference brand in this market. In France, we benefit from the _100% Santé changes, which make hearing aids significantly more affordable than they were previously. The 100% Santé changes were a disruption in the hearing aid market, resulting in a remarkable growth of approximately 85.0% in volume of devices sold in 2021, as reported by Snitem. Notwithstanding the current slowdown in the market (which was a consequence of the significant growth that we witnessed in 2021), we believe these regulatory changes will ultimately fuel growth in coming years, from 2025 onwards, as the sales volume of hearing aids will benefit from strong intrinsic growth driven by the public’s need for hearing aid devices. This need is largely due to an aging and growing population with a growing concern for hearing impairment, coupled with continued growth of hearing aid penetration rates and a supportive healthcare reimbursement system in France, which considerably improved with the implementation of 100% Santé. Including both hearing aids and optical products in the same stores generates synergies and crossselling opportunities. As of July 31, 2023, approximately 34.0% of our optical stores were equipped with hearing aid corners, compared to 20.0% as of July 31, 2019. Our combined offering also provides consumers with the convenience of acquiring both products at a single location, based on the fact that there is substantial overlap in the population seeking vision correction and the population seeking hearing aids. On the other hand, both opticians and hearing aid specialists in our network also benefit from these synergies, with opticians welcoming new potential clients under the hearing aid offers and hearing aid specialists benefiting from premium locations inside our optical network and a better management of the flow of customers with the support of the opticians on site. In the past five fiscal years and the nine months ended April 30, 2024, opticians welcoming a hearing aid corner inside their optical store have witnessed an average outperformance of 2% compared to the rest of our network. The below table shows how our hearing aid business has expanded from the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019 to the three months ended April 30, 2024. ----- _Source: Company information._ The strong growth of our hearing aid businesses has contributed to growth of our network sales (excluding Optical Discount) at a CAGR of 3.6% during the periods shown below. _Source: Company Information._ (1) Excluding Optical Discount. Additionally, we believe that our strong brand equity will benefit from the growth of each network. This was observed after the re-launch of hearing aids in Spain during the fiscal years ended July 31, 2022 and 2023, where total like-for-like sales grew 88.4% and 92.8%, respectively. We continue to focus on optimizing these synergies and have favored expansion of our hearing aid business through corners inside optical stores. Our hearing aid corners are a key growth lever for us, as we believe the hearing aid market is well-poised for significant growth. We believe there is significant upside to putting hearing aid corners in our franchisees’ existing optical stores, as the two businesses are complementary and we believe that these hearing aid corners drive like-for-like growth in sales of glasses. Our model envisions franchisees who wish to enter the hearing aids business operating their dedicated optical stores alongside two to three hearing aid corners. We believe this approach is a natural fit for many of ----- our franchisees, particularly for those who are dually-qualified as opticians and audiologists, as well as for those who aim to expand their existing competency to cover audiology as well as optical services. As of July 31, 2023 (excluding Optical Discount), we had 276 hearing aid corners inside 808 optical stores in France, 119 hearing aid corners inside 355 optical stores in Spain (where we prioritized the opening of hearing aid corners inside optical stores to drive our expansion in this region) and seven hearing aid corners in Belgium. Finally, we believe that using the same model in our hearing aid business as we do in our optical business will generate economies of scale in the future and help us to generate favorable levels of profitability.

Subsubsection Title: Further penetrate the European market in border countries and continue to expand in other international areas
Subsubsection Text: We have a well-established and expanding presence in countries that are adjacent to our core markets of France and Spain, having successfully expanded ALAIN AFFLELOU into Belgium (1998), Luxembourg (2002), Switzerland (2005) and Portugal (2008), respectively managing 50, five, 20 and 23 stores as of April 30, 2024. We believe that these “border” markets collectively represent millions of potential end-customers and thus present a significant potential growth opportunity for us, as these are familiar markets to us where we already have a fairly mature base, where we can roll-out the same operating model we use in France and Spain and where we benefit from built-in brand awareness. We intend to further extend our European footprint in these border countries (i.e. Belgium, Luxembourg, Switzerland and Portugal) by deepening our franchise network. In both Belgium and Switzerland, we are mainly present in French-speaking regions and we are seeking to grow our presence in Dutch-speaking regions of Belgium and German-speaking regions of Switzerland, which represent large markets in each of these countries. In Portugal, we are currently reviewing our strategy to expand beyond our existing base. We continuously evaluate potential targets for strategic acquisitions, particularly in such border countries. We also believe there are opportunities in the Middle East, where we see room to grow, as well as in Africa, where there is an increasing middle class, as well as a growing population with more disposable income, and especially in African countries that have a historical link with France, like Morocco, where we currently have 22 franchised stores as at April 30, 2024. We believe that our franchise model adapts well to various geographies, languages and types of markets. Our international roll-out expansion in those new geographies rests on limited costs and risk strategy, with a model operating through master franchise agreements, where potential is limited.

Subsubsection Title: Drive organic growth through market independence with our own brand, innovation and digitalization
Subsubsection Text: Our digital transformation is underpinned by the following six pillars: (1) Our ability to gather and analyze data through our CRM tools to better meet the needs of our end customers. (2) Our interactions with end customers through digital tools such as campaigns, online appointments, text messages, emails, digital reminders, and ratings on Google. (3) Our ability to optimize our communications with our customers as a result of better knowledge of our customers’ needs and utilizing social networks and digital communication. (4) Our continued improvement of the in-store customer journey through digital tools such as virtual try-ons and interactive screens, as well as tablets to improve customer interaction during the sale of our products. ----- (5) Our ability to deploy a first-mover offer in teleophthalmology and teleaudiology solutions. (6) Our continued focus on maintaining our online sales. Our digital transformation plan relies on a data-centric approach, in which we have made significant investments and have achieved notable success in recent years. We have a large customer database and have put in place strong support system from our franchisees and links with their point-of-sale systems, which we believe helps us to offer better service to customers. We believe that continuing to implement our digital transformation plan, including by optimizing our existing framework and rolling out new tools will help us increase the loyalty of our existing clients and as well as to attract new clients. Part of our digital transformation plan also involves the roll-out of digital screens, tablets and other innovative tools that are aimed at improving the customer experience in the store. Through our Orchestra program, we are providing our franchisees a complete solution to manage interactions with their end customers, beginning from the purchase of glasses in our stores. On the communication side, we also intend to continue growing our leading presence on various social media platforms, as a growing part of our total communication efforts. Finally, we intend to strengthen the multi-channel experience we offer to our customers. We currently have a “click-and-mortar” approach that allows customers to explore our products online and also test them through our virtual try-on session before ultimately buying products in one of our stores. Through our online offers at Afflelou.com and Malentille.com, we also continue to serve customers online. Customer surveys regularly identify our brand as a leader in terms of innovation. As such, we have started to deploy teleophthalmology in the ALAIN AFFLELOU in France, of which 121 were active as of April 30, 2024. The teleophthalmology solution at ALAIN AFFLELOU provides an alternative for glasses wearers to resolve the shortage of ophthalmologists, which is partly due to _numerus clausus for this profession, through a direct virtual consultation conducted by health professionals (orthoptists and ophthalmologists) in a dedicated space at the franchisees’ premises. The stores which have deployed teleophthalmology have witnessed a 5.7% outperformance of the rest of our network as we believe they bring an obvious benefit to people with vision impairment, who are facing growing difficulties to get a prescription for glasses, and are generally keen on simplifying the process to equip with glasses. We believe our teleophthalmology solution is a strong innovation in our sector, differentiating us from other businesses and bringing a large benefit for glasses wearers in a context of a shortage of ophthalmologists, especially in more rural areas. We are also currently testing the deployment of a similar telemedicine solution for our hearing aids business, with the aim to bring a solution to the shortage of ENT specialists, which impacts this market. On top of our innovative strategy, we are actively involved in the deployment of our own branded collections such as our Magic collection, which differentiates us from the rest of the industry. We believe our own brand proposition brings strong independence to our banner and provides us additional flexibility to match evolving consumer trends.

Subsubsection Title: Leverage operating efficiencies and network synergies
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue growing our store network in every geographical area, by enhancing our brand image, including by promoting awareness of our banners and commercial offers, remaining engaged with customers and potential customers through innovative communications campaigns and granting adequate support and services to enhance franchisees customer service and financial performance, including by providing opening, day-to-day and ad hoc support, such as through access to our central purchasing unit services and by expanding our prêt-à-porter logistics platform and customer relations training programs that acquaint franchisees and their employees with the benefits of our latest commercial offers. We believe these services increase customer satisfaction and improve performance in our stores, which are key drivers of our financial performance. We will continue to extend a variety of services that we have put in place in recent years, like training (including e-training) for our franchises and dedicated support such as our Elite program, which is designed to assist franchisees that are underperforming. Additionally, we intend to continue our rollout of a multi-offer approach, converting existing franchisees into operators under both our optical and hearing aid businesses, such as by ----- encouraging optical franchisees to add hearing aid or sunglasses corners in their stores. We believe that our strong focus on cultivating and promoting our franchisee-centered business model will continue to support robust levels of revenue per store in France and Spain, which have historically outperformed independent retailers’ levels of sales.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to deliver operating efficiencies at Group-level and generate network synergies
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to take advantage of the economies of scale provided by our network organization by streamlining our administrative and overhead functions and controlling our cost base. For instance, we have regrouped our various administrative locations in France at one site in Paris. We intend to continue evaluating the performance of our store network, with a view to optimizing such performance. We will also continue to carefully monitor our directly-owned stores network, with a long-term target of maintaining a limited directly-owned stores perimeter, while acting opportunistically where we believe there is low-risk potential. In France, we plan to reduce our directly-owned stores perimeter, limiting this perimeter to stores located in the Paris region, and to stores which either (i) require significant expenses due to their location and size (for example, large stores generally located in large shopping centers for which rents can often represent more than €150,000 per year) or (ii) have a strong impact on our overall image (flagship stores). In addition, we aim to dispose of isolated stores where our footprint of directlyowned stores is limited, and keep geographical clusters, such as in Lyon, Bordeaux and Marseille. We plan to sell any stores that do not correspond to these criteria to our franchisees. Notwithstanding these strategic reductions, we plan to continue to leverage our directly-owned stores in managing our wider network, operating flagship stores, and in our negotiations with suppliers. We also intend to continue our advertising efforts to support the development of our network as we did in Spain in the past fiscal year through a specific communication budget to support the relaunch of the hearing aid network. We will more generally continue to prioritize and fund significant communication campaigns, which for instance have been set at 8.76% of franchisees’ sales in France in July 2022, while leveraging our economies of scale to manage overall communication expenses. In particular, we believe that the rapid growth of our hearing aid business will generate a benefit to the brand equity of ALAIN AFFLELOU. We will also grow the synergies between the two complementary businesses, which share the same customer approach and the ALAIN AFFLELOU brand image, through the corners inside our optical stores. We are currently focused on generating synergies, through our Boost program, which aims at growing cross fertilization, alongside the expansion of our hearing aid network inside our optical stores network. In addition, we intend to continue leveraging our long-standing relationships with suppliers to obtain the most favorable commercial terms for our store network. Savings generated from these discounts or rebates are shared with franchisees. Finally, we believe that expanding in border countries and growing our hearing aid business will help us increase profitability due to both gains in communication margins and the growth of exclusive products.

Subsubsection Title: A CSR policy embedded into the Group strategy
Subsubsection Text: In 2022, we accelerated the integration of our corporate social responsibility policy into our strategic plans, with a focus on three main pillars derived from our motto to make our products accessible to as many people as possible: (i) Reach the highest standards in terms of environmental protection through our own branded products, deploying eco-conception, and collections of sunglasses like H2O. We produced our first carbon footprint report in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2024, and we are currently defining our trajectory for a CO2 emissions reduction plan. In addition, we are also involved in waste reduction, and recycling glasses and hearing aids products which are delivered in our network. We intend to support the optimization of our supply chain including logistics matters that are aimed at reducing CO2 emissions or favor processes such as cut-edged and premounted glasses which can deliver significant levels of CO2 emissions savings. ----- (ii) Consider the health dimension of our business with our foundation to grant assistance to populations in need of glasses and hearing aid devices where the government provides lower protection. In addition, in some cases (such as in our teleophthalmology initiative) we aim to facilitate access to health professionals in so-called “medical deserts” where access to health professionals is lacking. (iii) Provide greater support to our franchisees through training. In addition, we aim to grow our Adelante financial support program to provide opportunities to young opticians and audioprosthetists to become entrepreneurs and benefit from career opportunities which they could not otherwise access without such support. These pillars are conducted alongside our internal efforts to align our business to the European Union’s Education of Social Responsibility objectives. In addition, we adhere to the United Nations’ Global Compact in July 2022 and we have also established a series of initiatives internally, with our own employees, to favor diversity and inclusion.

Our strategy has six pillars: (i) increase our franchise network footprint in our domestic markets through new store openings while continuing to optimize our efficiently-managed network and enhance our ----- multi-channel offering; (ii) accelerate our expansion in the hearing aid markets in largely underpenetrated markets, through our corners inside the optical network; (iii) further penetrate the European market in border countries and continue to seize opportunities in other regions; (iv) drive organic growth through marketing innovation, like our _Magic_ collection and the teleophthalmology solution; (v) leverage operating efficiencies and network synergies between the optical and hearing aid businesses and (vi) expand our CSR policy into the Group’s strategy.

The Issuer is the reporting entity for the Group and was incorporated on April 20, 2012. It is organized as a société par actions simplifiée under the laws of France. The Issuer is registered in France under sole identification number 751 095 712 R.C.S. Nanterre. The Issuer’s registered office and principal business address is Tour Trinity 1 bis, Esplanade de la Défense, 92400 Courbevoie, France.

The beneficial ownership of the share capital of the Issuer is as follows (in each case, through one or more holding entities) as at April 30, 2024: - NALA AFFLELOU BIDCO Ltd controlled by Lion Capital: 71.25%; - HOLDING AA-OC controlled by Mr. Alain Afflelou and his family: 28.53%; and - MARELLE PARTNERS controlled by Rachel Marouani: 0.22%. The Issuer’s share capital is also composed of class 1 preferred shares, which carry specific financial rights depending on the Issuer’s business development (i.e. the right to be allocated a portion of the proceeds of the other shareholders upon occurrence of a liquidity event (Évènement de Liquidité as such term is defined in the Issuer’s articles of association) if the internal rate of return realized by such shareholders between June 30, 2022 and the date of such liquidity event exceeds certain thresholds), but no dividend rights. A portion of these shares are held by Marelle Partners and the other portion of these shares have been allocated for free to management. Lion Capital is a consumer-focused investor passionate about driving growth through strong brands. With offices in London and the United States, the firm’s principals have invested in 44 businesses and more than 175 consumer brands across Europe and North America. Lion’s focus on market-leading consumer-facing companies has led to investments in such well-known brands as AllSaints, a global contemporary fashion company; Grenade, a market leading sports performance and active nutrition brand; Jimmy Choo, a worldwide luxury accessories brand; Kettle Foods, a leading global producer of all-natural snacking products; Loungers, a fast-growing UK chain of informal all-day neighborhood cafébars; wagamama, the UK’s leading chain of pan-Asian inspired noodle restaurants and Weetabix, a leading branded manufacturer of ready-to-eat cereals and cereal bars in the United Kingdom. See “Principal Shareholders and Related Party Transactions”. -----

We have obtained commitments from lenders for a New Revolving Credit Facility of €30.0 million to be entered into on or prior to the Issue Date, under which the Issuer will be permitted to draw from time to time. The Issuer, 3AB Optique Développement and Alain Afflelou Franchiseur are the original borrowers and guarantors and, within 90 days of the Issue Date, Alain Afflelou International and L’Opticien Afflelou will become guarantors under the New Revolving Credit Facility. For a description of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit _Facility”._

Subsubsection Title: Tender Offer in Respect of the Existing Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we have launched an offer to purchase for cash any and all of our outstanding Existing Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Regulation S by noteholders outside of the United States (the “Tender Offer”). The Tender Offer is being made upon terms and subject to the conditions set out in the separate tender offer memorandum dated the date hereof (the “Tender Offer

We intend to use the gross proceeds from this Offering to (i) repay the Existing Notes, which is expected to consist of a combination of (a) funding the consideration to be paid in connection with the Tender Offer which will settle concurrently with the Offering, (b) funding the satisfaction and discharge on or about the Issue Date and subsequent redemption of the Remaining Existing Senior Secured Notes on May 19, 2025 and (c) funding the redemption price to redeem the Existing Subordinated Notes on or about the Issue Date, (ii) fund, along with €86.9 million of cash on balance sheet, the Shareholder Distribution; and (iii) pay commissions, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the foregoing. For more details, see “Use of Proceeds”.

Subsection Title: Memorandum”). The Tender Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions,
Subsubsection Title: Satisfaction and Discharge of the Existing Senior Secured Notes and Redemption of the Existing Subordinated Notes
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Transactions, the Existing Notes will be fully repaid as follows: (i) on or about the Issue Date, the Issuer expects to deposit with the Existing Notes Trustee an amount in cash or cash equivalents sufficient to make the regularly scheduled interest payment on November 19, 2024 and to subsequently redeem such Existing Senior Secured Notes not validly tendered and accepted for purchase by the Issuer pursuant to the Tender Offer (the “Remaining Existing Senior Secured Notes”) at par on or around May 19, 2025, along with unpaid and accrued interest up to, but excluding such date; and (ii) on or about the Issue Date, the Issuer expects to redeem in full the Existing Subordinated Notes at 102.000%, plus accrued and unpaid interest from May 19, 2024 to, but excluding such redemption date. ----- The Issuer will also take any other necessary actions to extinguish the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ obligations in respect of the Existing Notes on or about the Issue Date and release the related guarantees and security interests. Upon deposit of the funds in respect of the Remaining Existing Senior Secured Notes and the redemption of the Existing Subordinated Notes in accordance with the Existing Notes Indentures, the Existing Notes Indentures and the rights of the Existing Notes Trustees and the holders thereof under the Intercreditor Agreement and the security documents in respect of the Existing Notes will be discharged and cease to be of further effect. This Offering Memorandum does not constitute notice of redemption of the Existing Notes which will be delivered in accordance with the terms of the Existing Notes Indentures. Though it is the Issuer’s current intention to proceed with a satisfaction and discharge of the Remaining Existing Senior Secured Notes on or about the Issue Date and their subsequent redemption on May 19, 2025, the Issuer is not obligated to undertake the aforementioned satisfaction and discharge, and there can be no assurance that it will consummate such satisfaction and discharge as described herein, or at all. In the alternative, the Issuer may opt to terminate the Tender Offer and proceed to redeem the Existing Senior Secured Notes on or about the Issue Date. Any such redemption and/or satisfaction and discharge of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will only be made in accordance with the provisions of the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indenture.

Subsection Title: Memorandum”). The Tender Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions,
Subsubsection Text: On or around the Issue Date, the Issuer will use cash on balance sheet and a portion of the proceeds from the Offering to make a distribution to its Shareholders, which is expected to be paid as a share premium distribution (distribution de prime d’émission). See “Use of Proceeds”. The term “Transactions” means, collectively, (i) the Offering, (ii) the Tender Offer, (iii) the satisfaction and discharge of the Remaining Existing Senior Secured Notes on or about the Issue Date and subsequent redemption on May 19, 2025, (iv) the redemption of the Existing Subordinated Notes at 102.000% on or about the Issue Date, (v) the Shareholder Distribution, (vi) the entering into of the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and the cancellation of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, (vii) the entering into of the New Intercreditor Agreement and (viii) the payment of fees and expenses therewith. -----

Subsection Title: Memorandum”). The Tender Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions,
Subsubsection Text: including, but not limited to, the consummation of the Offering, on terms satisfactory to the Issuer in its sole discretion. We cannot assure you that the Tender Offer will be consummated in accordance with its terms, or at all, or that any of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and purchased in the Tender Offer. The Offering is not conditioned upon the consummation of the Tender Offer. This Offering Memorandum does not relate to the Tender Offer, which is only made upon the terms and subject to the conditions set out in the Tender Offer Memorandum, and is only made to certain eligible holders of Existing Senior Secured Notes holding book-entry interests in the Regulation S global note.

_This summary contains basic information about us and the Transactions, and highlights information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum about the Transactions and our business, financial performance and prospects. This summary does not contain all of the information that may be important to you in deciding to invest in the Notes and it is qualified in its entirety by the more detailed information and financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should read the entire Offering Memorandum, including the sections entitled “Risk Factors”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, “Industry” and “Business” as well as the financial statements and related notes contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment decision._

Subsection Title: Date Collateral”). Within 90 days of the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by first-priority liens and over collateral
Subsubsection Text: consisting of (i) all shares issued by or held in Alain Afflelou International and (ii) pledges of certain bank accounts of the Post-Issue Date Guarantors (collectively, the “Post-Issue Date Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the _Guarantees and the Security Interests” for certain legal considerations that may limit the enforceability of the security_ interests in the Collateral. The Collateral may also be released in certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes— _Security—Release of Liens”. The Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering as further described under “Summary— The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds”._ (3) The Issuer is a société par actions simplifiée organized under the laws of France. (4) The New Revolving Credit Facility will provide for up to €30.0 million of senior secured revolving credit. The Issuer, 3AB Optique Développement and Alain Afflelou Franchiseur are the original borrowers and guarantors and, within 90 days of the Issue Date, Alain Afflelou International and L’Opticien Afflelou will become guarantors under the New Revolving Credit Facility. For further information on the New Revolving Credit Facility, see “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness and _Other Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility”._ (5) On or around the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed by 3AB Optique Développement and Alain Afflelou Franchiseur (collectively, the “Issue Date Guarantors”) and, within 90 days of the Issue Date, by Alain Afflelou International and L’Opticien Afflelou (the “Post-Issue Date Guarantors” and, together with the Issue Date Guarantors, the “Guarantors”). The Notes will be general senior obligations of the Issuer, will be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Guarantees”) by the Guarantors, will rank equally in right of payment to all other existing and future senior obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors, respectively, and will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. The Guarantees will be subject to certain limitations as described under “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the _Security Interests” and may be released in certain circumstances. See “The Offering—Guarantees” and “Risk Factors”._ (6) Certain operating subsidiaries of the Group are organized under the laws of France as well as certain other jurisdictions where we are present, including, among others, Spain, Belgium, Portugal and Luxembourg. Although the Indenture will impose certain limitations on the amount of indebtedness that can be incurred by the Issuer and its subsidiaries, any indebtedness incurred by the subsidiaries of the Issuer in compliance with the Indenture will be structurally senior to the ----- Notes to the extent that such subsidiaries do not guarantee the Notes or the amount of their guarantees is less than the principal amount of the outstanding Notes, and, within certain limitations, may be secured by other assets or receivables, making such indebtedness, effectively senior to the Notes. In the event of a bankruptcy or liquidation of any of these subsidiaries, such subsidiaries will pay the holders of their respective debt and their respective trade creditors before they will be able to distribute any of their assets to their respective parent entities and ultimately to the Issuer. -----

The following chart shows a simplified summary of the corporate and financing structure and nominal amounts of the principal indebtedness of the Group as of April 30, 2024 after giving effect to the Transactions. The chart does not include all entities in the Group, nor all of the debt obligations thereof. All entities shown below are, unless otherwise indicated, directly or indirectly owned by their respective parent company. Outstanding debt amounts are based on the nominal value figures as of April 30, 2024, as adjusted for the Transactions. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections entitled “Description of the Notes”, “Description of Certain Other _Indebtedness and Other Arrangements” and “Capitalization”._ (1) On or around the Issue Date, the Issuer will be indirectly owned by (i) Mr. Alain Afflelou and members of his family via Holding AA-OC (28.53%), (ii) the Sponsor via Nala Afflelou Bidco Limited (71.25%) and (iii) Marelle Partners (0.22%). See “Principal Shareholders and Related Party Transactions” for more information. (2) On or around the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by first-priority liens over collateral consisting of (i) pledges of certain securities accounts relating to all securities issued by or held in 3AB Optique Développement, Alain Afflelou Franchiseur and L’Opticien Afflelou, (ii) pledges of certain bank accounts of the Issuer and the Issue Date Guarantors and (iii) pledges of certain intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer and the Issue Date Guarantors (collectively, the “Issue

accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date plus a “make whole” premium as described under “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption”._ At any time on or after, 2026, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum. At any time prior to, 2026, the Issuer may on one or more occasions redeem up to % of the principal amount of the Notes, using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption; provided that at least % of the aggregate original principal amount of the Notes remains outstanding after the redemption. See “Description of the _Notes—Optional redemption”._ In the event of certain developments affecting taxation or certain other circumstances which would require the Issuer or a Guarantor to pay additional amounts, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption _for taxation reasons”._ Additional Amounts ................................** Any payments made by the Issuer with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes unless required by law. If the Issuer or Guarantor is required by law of a relevant taxing jurisdiction to withhold or deduct for such taxes with respect to a payment to the holders of Notes, the Issuer or the applicable Guarantor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of Notes after the withholding is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the Notes— _Withholding taxes”._ Original Issue Discount: ........................** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, investors in the Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in their gross income for U.S. federal income tax purposes as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash payments attributable to such income, using the constant yield method.
