Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our main business consists of our franchisor activity in the optical and hearing aid product markets. As franchisor, we provide our franchisees with a full range of solutions and services, making our networks, industry know-how and business practices available to them, while also marketing and promoting our networks and offering a broad, appealing range of purchasing solutions, including exclusive product offers. All of these products and services maintain brand appeal and pave the way for the development of our franchisees. In exchange for these services and the exclusive products provided to franchisees, we charge the cost of goods as well as fees and other contributions to our franchisees (in accordance with franchise agreements) and to network suppliers. ----- Furthermore, to support our networks, we also directly own a number of optical and hearing aid product stores. The three-part objective of our directly-owned stores is to support our franchisor activity as follows: - maintain complete control over flagship stores in strategic areas in terms of customer bases, as these stores are considered to be showcases for our networks; - operate a portfolio of stores to test new business initiatives, product concepts and innovations and identify best practices in operations and distribution before rolling them out across the network; and - manage the store network by temporarily operating stores where a franchisee is retiring or experiencing financial difficulties. In these cases, we acquire the stores to keep them within the network, with the objective of transferring them to new franchisees in the short- to mid-term. We recognize the following geographical segments in accordance with IFRS 8 – Operating Segments: - **_France. The France segment, which includes the optical and hearing aid businesses of franchised and directly-owned stores in France (as well as the activities of Malentille.com), accounted for 75.9% of network sales and 75.5% of our revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. As of April 30, 2024, we had a total of 914 stores in France, of which 76 were directly-owned; - **_Spain. The “Spain” segment, which includes the optical and hearing aid businesses of franchised and directly-owned stores in Spain (including Andorra), accounted for 16.4% of network sales and 20.6% of our revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. As of April 30, 2024, we had a total of 368 stores in Spain, of which 89 were directly-owned stores; and - **_Other countries. The “Other countries” segment, which includes the optical business in countries outside France and Spain, accounted for 7.8% of network sales and 3.9% of our revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. As of April 30, 2024, we had a total of 152 stores in our Other countries segment, of which 6 were directly-owned stores in Portugal. See “Presentation of _Financial and Other Information—Segment Information”._ We generate revenue through (i) network sales revenue, mainly comprising fees, contributions and other revenue collected by us on franchisee sales in exchange for the various services we provide them as franchisor; (ii) network purchases revenue; and (iii) revenue from directly-owned stores. These sources of revenue are further described below. - **_Network sales revenue (i). Network sales revenue is mainly derived from fees calculated on the basis of a percentage of the sales reported by the network of franchised stores and from initial one-time network entry fees. Network sales revenue represented 26.6% of our revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024 and 27.8% of network sales over the same period. These fees and contributions mainly comprise the following items: - _Entry fees and royalties. Our store network benefits from the industry know-how and commercial expertise that we have developed over the years, as well as from our strong brand recognition and reputation. We are responsible for formulating a commercial strategy, which is supported by innovative offers, the development of products and services and the sharing of best practices within the store network. In exchange for our know-how, the right to use one of our brands and operate under one of our networks, and the allocation of an exclusive geographical area, we charge franchisees an initial one-time entry fee. For example, we charge entry fees of up to €50,000 for ALAIN AFFLELOU in France. For all of our networks, we charge monthly royalties which are calculated as a percentage of a store’s monthly sales excluding VAT, which, for example, are set at a standard 4.15% rate for ALAIN AFFLELOU in France and at a standard 4.23% rate for ALAIN AFFLELOU in Spain. - _Communications. We are responsible for the development and implementation of our network’s advertising and communications strategy, using different types of media (TV, radio) ----- on a local level as well as on national levels to promote our brands, product offerings and commercial offers. In exchange for the communications services we provide, we receive communication fees from stores in the network, which are calculated as a percentage of a store’s monthly sales including VAT, which for example are set at 7.3% for ALAIN AFFLELOU in France (including VAT) and 8.34% for ALAIN AFFLELOU in Spain (excluding VAT). Communication activity also includes special services charged to the store network as part of local communications campaigns. In addition, revenue derived from communications activities includes sales of display models of exclusive eyeglass frames to stores in the network (however, this revenue is eliminated in the consolidation, as it is also reflected in our exclusive product trading revenue). - _Other. These contributions comprise various services charged to the store network, such as training and overhead (e.g., IT expenses), as well as various fees charged to suppliers and service providers for network commercial offers. - **_Network purchases revenue (ii)._** Network purchases revenue is derived from listing- and licensing-related fees charged to suppliers on their sales to franchisees, and wholesale activity consisting of product sales to franchisees through central purchasing units and our exclusive eyeglass frames and sunglasses trading activity. Our network purchases revenue represented 43.9% of revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024 and 41.4% of network sales over the same period. Network purchases revenue comprises the following types of revenue: - _Central listing and payment units._ Stores in the network are required to purchase all the products they sell exclusively from suppliers that are listed by our central listing and payment units. On behalf of stores in the network, we negotiate purchasing terms with these suppliers and operate central listing and payment units to optimize the supply and payment of products for both suppliers and stores in the network. The central listing and payment units afford suppliers the advantage of a single commercial and financial counterparty for the entire network, in addition to guaranteed settlements from the network’s franchisees. In exchange for these listing and payment services, we charge listed suppliers listing fees (comprising listing commissions, del credere commissions relating to supplier payment guarantees and early payment allowances). Such listing fees are calculated as a percentage of a listed supplier’s sales to stores in the network. - _Central purchasing units. Stores in the network purchase products either directly from listed suppliers or through our central purchasing units in France, Spain and Belgium. Our central purchasing units primarily cover the purchase of eyeglass lenses, contact lenses and Afflelou-exclusive frames and sunglasses. This system helps network franchisees receive additional discounts, of which we receive a share. - _Licensing._ We provide stores in the network our own-brand eyeglass lenses and contact lenses, which are manufactured by third parties and distributed by us through our central purchasing units or directly by listed suppliers. We charge third-party manufacturers of our own-brand eyeglass lenses and contact lenses a licensing fee for the use of certain brand names, which are calculated as a percentage of the supplier’s sales to stores in the network. - _Exclusive product trading. We act as a wholesaler by selling exclusive frames and sunglasses to stores in the network either through logistics providers or directly. Exclusive products include: (i) proprietary frames and sunglasses, which are frames and sunglasses selected by us, manufactured by subcontractors according to our specifications and sold under our own brands, such as the “Afflelou” signature label; (ii) frames and sunglasses under exclusive licenses, which are frames selected by us, manufactured by subcontractors according to our specifications and marketed under third-party brands; and (iii) other exclusive brands and third-party names, which are designed and manufactured by third parties for exclusive distribution in the store network. As part of our trading activities, we retain a margin on the sale of exclusive frames and sunglasses to stores in the network. ----- - **_Directly-owned stores revenue (iii). We also generate revenue from sales to end customers at directly-owned stores. The directly-owned store network’s contribution to our costs (such as rent and personnel costs) and revenue represents a relatively substantial portion of overall costs and revenue, as it corresponds to the costs and sales of the stores (borne by us), whereas the franchisor activity is largely based on royalties collected from network sales and the sale of products to franchisees. At April 30, 2024, we operated 76 directly-owned stores in France, 89 directly-owned stores in Spain, and six directly-owned stores in Other countries (in Portugal). Revenue from directly-owned stores accounted for 29.6% of revenue for the nine months ended April 30, 2024.

Subsubsection Text: A significant portion of our revenue is directly generated by network sales (revenue from franchisees) which include all optical and hearing aid sales generated by the stores in our network and on our websites. Network sales are reported monthly by our franchisees in accordance with the provisions of the franchise agreements. The various fees charged to franchisees, such as royalties and communication fees, are calculated as a percentage of franchisee sales. Revenue from central purchasing and payment units is also related to network business, but indirectly since such revenue is generated by charges to suppliers (listing and payment service fees, and distribution royalties) related to network procurement or a margin retained on franchisee purchases (central purchasing units and trading), and ultimately depends on competition of listed products with those of other suppliers. As a result, network sales are the main factor affecting our revenue, which in turn affects our results of operations, particularly our profitability. ----- The following table provides a breakdown of network sales (excluding VAT) by geographical area for the periods indicated:

Subsubsection Text: of which centers ........................................_ _108_ _99_ _98_ 112 103 of which retail spaces ................................_ _402_ _344_ _298_ 447 377 _Fiscal year ended July 31, 2023_ In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our ALAIN AFFLELOU network sales increased by 6.0% to €876.1 million compared to €826.6 million in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 (taking into consideration the discontinuation of our Optical Discount banner, network sales increased by 3.9% from €859.5 million to €893.4 million over those periods). While our optical sales performed well in all of our geographies, our hearing aid activity recorded contrasted performance across our different geographies during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, with a decline in France due to the regularization of the market as a result of a continued slowdown after the implementation of _100% Santé in 2021, and simultaneous rapid growth of this business in Spain. _France_ In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our total network sales in France reported an overall growth of 5.0% to €667.1 million compared to €635.7 million in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. This increase was due a growth of 6.4% in our optical business. Our optical business significantly outperformed the market, which increased by of 4.0% (like-for-like sales) as estimated by Xerfi and by 4.1% (total sales) as estimated by GfK. During this same period, our hearing aid business recorded a decline of 8.3%, an evolution consistent with the overall market which declined by approximately 7% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, as reported by sales volume estimates recorded by the suppliers union in the hearing aids sector. Notwithstanding this decline, we have continued to strongly expand our footprint of hearing aid points of sale. _Spain_ In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our total network sales in Spain increased by 10.5% to €141.3 million compared to €127.9 million in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. This increase was due to growth of our (i) optical sales which grew by 7.8%, strongly outperforming the market and (ii) hearing aid business which grew by 92.8%. We aim to increase our hearing aid sales in Spain, which currently represents approximately 5.8% of our optical sales, so that it reaches the same proportion of total network sales in France, where hearing aid sales currently represent 9.1% of our optical sales. ----- _Other countries_ In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our total network sales in the Other countries segment recorded growth of 7.3% to €67.6 million compared to €63.0 million in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. This positive performance stems from the expansion of our network with solid partners in most areas of operation in this segment. _Nine months ended April 30, 2024_ Network sales increased by 5.4% to €677.7 million during the nine months ended April 30, 2024 compared to €643.2 million during the nine months ended April 30, 2023. _France_ Network sales in France increased by 4.5% in the nine months ended April 30, 2024 compared to the same period in the previous fiscal year. Our optical business continued to grow well, despite a limited communication presence prior to our new communication campaign that started in April. In addition to the solid performance at our optical business, our hearing aid business continued its progressive recovery, with an increase in network sales of 1.9% during the nine months ended April 30, 2024 compared to the nine months ended April 30, 2023. The positive sales performance at our hearing network were accompanied as in past periods by the continued expansion of our network which reached 394 points of sales as at the end of April 2024 (of which 292 were corners inside optical stores). _Spain_ In the nine months ended April 30, 2024, network sales in Spain reported a total growth of 8.3% compared to the same period in the prior fiscal year. In this same period, our hearing aid business continued to record strong growth of 51.2% compared to nine months ended April 30, 2023. This performance was supported by a rapid expansion of the network to 152 points of sales as at April 30, 2024 compared to 117 points of sales as at April 30, 2023. _Other countries_ Network sales in the Other countries segment grew during the nine months ended April 30, 2024 to €52.6 million, or 7.9%, compared to the nine months ended April 30, 2023. Sales in Belgium represented an increase of 7.8% on a cumulated basis in the nine months ended April 30, 2024. This increase stems from solid commercial performance compared to a slightly negative evolution in the past year. Our sales in Belgium allowed us to confidently launch our hearing aid business. We have 13 hearing aid corners inside our Belgium network of 50 stores. In Switzerland, sales continued to record growth of 6.4%. The sales in the other international areas continued to grow, with solid performance in Portugal and Morocco, together making up more than 20 stores.

Subsubsection Text: The growth in like-for-like network sales for a given period corresponds to the increase in sales in stores which were open throughout the entire relevant period under consideration and the entire prior year and for which no substantial changes (such as construction or refurbishment work with a duration of more than one month) or closures have occurred during the period under consideration. In addition to expanding network sales generally, like-for-like network sales growth is another important indicator of the performance of our store network. For a definition of like-for-like network sales growth, see footnote 4 under “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data— _Operating and segment information”. In countries such as France and Spain, where we already have a_ significant store network, the size of the existing network plays a critical role in the overall growth of network sales. Further illustrating this, in a given period new stores only account for a small percentage of network sales. We analyze network sales growth on a like-for-like basis in France, Spain and the Other countries segment to assess the evolution of the performance of existing stores, excluding the effects of network expansion. Nevertheless, in the fast growing segment of our hearing aid business in Spain and in France, where our network grows rapidly in terms of points of sale, through the opening of corners to complement our optical activity, the like-for-like evolution is less meaningful, especially as corners may not be operated on a daily basis by an audio-prosthetist. Growth in like-for-like network sales is thanks to our implementation of commercial offers and policies and the marketing communications that promote them, but it is also due to the initiatives of local stores run by franchisees, which receive additional support from our sales management teams. Like-for-like network sales correspond to sales generated by stores which were open throughout the periods under review, based on a full fiscal year, and which did not undergo any substantial changes during such periods (such as construction or refurbishment work with a duration of more than one month), for sales performance in a period to be comparable to that of the prior period. The calculation of like-for-like network sales does not take store closures in connection with COVID-19 into account. Like-for-like network sales are calculated at constant exchange rates (applying the prior year’s exchange rates to the current year), as a very small portion of network sales are currently exposed to currency risk. Like-for-like network sales growth has not been adjusted based on the potential impact on network sales resulting from the different number of working days between two periods. The following table presents a breakdown of like-for-like network sales growth by geographical area for the periods indicated: -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Excluding Optical Discount. _Fiscal year ended July 31, 2023_ In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, the Group’s store count (excluding Optical Discount) grew by 45 stores from 1,373 stores the end of July 2022 to 1,418 stores at the end of July 2023. Following our decision in late 2022 to focus on our development of the ALAIN AFFLELOU banner, the total number of stores bearing our Optical Discount brand declined by 66 stores during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. As a consequence, in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, the total number of stores, including the discount banner, declined by 21 stores to 1,440 stores, compared to 1,461 in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Our strategy to focus on ALAIN AFFLELOU allowed us to accelerate the expansion during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, of our historical banner, including moving a few of our stores that fell under the discount banner to the ALAIN AFFLELOU banner. We also believe that focusing on our historical banner reinforces its leading brand awareness and the capacity to grow more rapidly our hearing aid banner, like in Spain where this activity has witnessed a rapid expansion in the past two fiscal years. Today, we operate under one banner: ALAIN AFFLELOU which includes geographical networks and specific audio and optical networks. Since the start of the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 we have been focused on the following action items: - a review of white space potential, together with a review of such potential with our existing franchisees, with around 150 locations identified for new store openings; - a communication plan that began in spring 2023 to attract new franchisee candidates, through professional and social media outreach in the optical sector; and - a program dedicated to our store managers to allow them to become franchisees, with buy back plans of some of our directly-owned stores. We believe our strategy to attract new franchisee candidates is key since we are facing a growing shortage of health professionals in both our hearing aid and optical businesses. The Adelante support we provide to franchisees also allows us to attract new candidates. As of July 31, 2023, approximately 140 of our stores in Spain and France have benefitted from our Adelante financial support program. Some stores have already been sold back to franchisees with a renewed capacity to grow sales, with limited expense on our side. As a result, the number of our directly-owned stores declined to 177 stores as at July 31, 2023 compared to 183 as at July 31, 2022, and this decline is expected to continue in France, with a long term aim of maintaining a proportion of approximately 10.0% directly-owned stores in our structure. _France_ Our French ALAIN AFFLELOU network increased by 28 stores for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. For the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our optical and hearing networks reached 908 stores compared to 882 stores for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Despite the more challenging outlook in the sector, ----- our hearing aid business continued to expand, with 376 points of sale, including 276 corners and 100 exclusive hearing aid centers for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, compared to 343 for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 (including 251 corners and 92 centers). Lastly, we have reduced our directly-owned stores perimeter to 83 stores for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, compared to 93 for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022, mainly through the sale of the stores we acquired in Normandy. In addition, we made the decision to focus our directly-owned store concentration in the Paris region, and on larger stores elsewhere in France, with an aim to sell additional directly-owned stores not corresponding to these criteria in the current fiscal year. _Spain_ In Spain, our store count grew by nine stores for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 to 363 stores. Following our decision to re-launch our hearing aid business, the network now comprises eight dedicated centers and 119 corners. In Spain, like in France, our strategy to grow synergies between the two businesses includes a growing coverage of the optical network through the proportion of optical stores with hearing aid corners. This proportion reached around one-third in both countries. _Other countries_ Our network in the Other countries segment grew by ten stores, to 147 ALAIN AFFLELOU stores for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 compared to 137 for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. We have a solid base in Switzerland and Belux with 20 stores and 54 stores in such regions, respectively. In each of those areas, we aim to expand the hearing aid business, as well as to grow our optical portfolio in the non-French speaking regions. In Belgium, we have started the expansion of our hearing aids business with seven corners opened during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. In Portugal, we have continued to grow our portfolio by three stores in the prior fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, reaching a portfolio of 26 stores, including six directly-owned stores. In the other international areas, we have continued to expand our footprint in the Middle East, where we have a total of 14 stores in Kuwait, Lebanon, United Arab Emirates, Armenia and Georgia, as at July 31, 2023. In Maghreb, we have 25 stores in Algeria and Morocco, with a strong position of 20 stores in Morocco, as at July 31, 2023. We plan to continue our expansion in the Middle East, especially in the Arabian Peninsula in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, where our performance has been positive since its inception. _Nine months ended April 30, 2024_ Our total store count increased by 37 stores to 1,434 stores as of April 30, 2024 compared to 1,397 stores as of April 30, 2023. Our portfolio of stores now consists of stores managed under ALAIN AFFLELOU (i.e. optical, hearing aid, and Alain Afflelou opticien & acousticien). Optical Discount is not included as we made the decision to progressively discontinue Optical Discount. During this period, our portfolio continued to develop well, with a net addition of 12 stores and overall growth of 37 stores compared to April 30, 2023 (excluding the expansion at our hearing aid network through the openings of 70 corners inside optical stores). _France_ Our total ALAIN AFFLELOU store count in France increased by 14 stores as at April 30, 2024 compared to April 30, 2023 as a result of various initiatives like our _Adelante_ program, targeted marketing to opticians demonstrating the benefits brought by joining ALAIN AFFLELOU as a franchisee, and allocating more resources to our internal Development Teams. The overall growth of our network also included the expansion of our hearing aid store count, with six additional centers (only dedicated to hearing aids) compared to April 30, 2023, and a total of 38 additional points of sales (including both centers and corners) now accounting for 394 points of sales compared to 356 as at April 30, 2023. Finally, we continued our plan to reduce our directly-owned stores portfolio, with the aim to focus on the Paris region, large profitable stores, and geographical and profitable clusters like we have in the Bordeaux region. The total number of directly-owned stores was brought back to 76 stores as at end of April 2024 compared to 86 a year before, with the aim to bring the total portfolio down to around 50 stores in the future. ----- _Spain_ Our store network continued to expand with 368 stores as of April 30, 2024 compared to 356 stores as at April 30, 2023. Our hearing aid network continued to expand rapidly, mainly through hearing corners, with a total number of points of sales of 152 compared to 117 as at April 30, 2023. Finally, our directlyowned stores perimeter gained one store, accounting for 89 stores as at April 30, 2024. _Other countries_ Other countries grew by eleven stores to 152 as at April 30, 2024 compared to 141 as at April 30, 2023. As at April 30, 2024, we had 55 stores in Belux, 23 stores in Portugal, 22 stores in Morocco, 20 stores in Switzerland, with the remainder including stores in Africa and the Middle East.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: _Business model and new services and offers_ Our ability to pivot our franchise business model, and in particular our ability to develop and offer new services to our franchisees and suppliers, across all our networks and geographies, has historically had, and may in the future have, a significant impact on our results of operations. ----- Average franchise and communication fees can change as our network changes. For example, when long-standing franchisees, which are often subject to historical royalty rates that are lower than current rates, retire and are replaced with new franchisees, we are able to obtain more favorable terms. Concerning revenue from franchisees, the new networks such as Acousticien or our new countries of operation (and in the past, our Optical Discount brand) that may have lower royalty rates, impacts our average franchise fees overall. In general, we invoice higher franchise and communication fees in France than in other countries, reflecting our strong brand recognition and considerable know-how. Newer networks such as Acousticien generally incur higher advertising expenditures to foster brand awareness and drive footfall. Additionally, we are progressively extending throughout our network the central listing and payment unit already in place in France and Spain, which covers all of franchisees’ purchases, as well as a central purchasing unit that helps franchisees to optimize the cost of purchases and boost their margins. Moreover, our ability to improve the terms of our agreements with suppliers, primarily attributable to the volume of purchases made within our network, may have an impact on our results. The roll-out of a line of exclusive products, notably through our trading activities can also have an effect on our network sales and revenue. Our ability to improve the penetration rate of these products in the overall purchases of franchisees in our network increases our revenue and profitability. _Directly-owned stores_ Any changes in sales at directly-owned stores impact our revenue, results of operations and financial position. Directly-owned store sales are included in network sales and are also impacted by the factors described above. The contribution of directly-owned stores to our costs and revenue represents a relatively substantial portion of overall costs and revenue, as it mainly corresponds to the costs and sales of these stores directly borne by us. Changes in the number of directly-owned stores therefore affect our cost structure and revenue generation. For example, in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022, we bought back two franchisee perimeters accounting for 20 stores and representing €17.0 million of annual sales, in Normandy (January 2022) and in Bordeaux (October 2021). The impact of these additional DOS affected our results of operations in that period compared to the prior one, relating to revenue and cost items. Our strategy for directly-owned stores is based around three major objectives: (i) retaining control over flagship stores located in strategic areas and key geographies; (ii) having a store network to test new business initiatives and identify best practices in operations and distribution before applying them to the franchisees; and (iii) managing the overall store network when the need arises, through supporting locations where the franchisee is either retiring or experiencing financial difficulties to keep the location within our networks. Setting and achieving these objectives is part of the overall management strategy for the network and involves specific costs, but it contributes to increasing the profitability of the entire franchise activity. Changes in the initiatives or the number of directly-owned stores could therefore impact our future results.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Excluding Optical Discount. In general, growth in like-for-like network sales is itself influenced by several factors, including: - _Population and lifestyle dynamics. Sales volumes are correlated with population growth and aging. Population growth in the geographical regions in which we operate will likely result in increased demand for optical products. Aging of the population is also expected to result in increased demand for optical products and hearing aids. As a person ages, the need for optical products and hearing aids increases due to age-related far-sightedness and hearing loss. See “Industry”. Evolving social habits and lifestyle patterns, such as growing exposure to digital displays, headphones and noisy environments, as well as increasing eye and hearing health awareness, are also expected to continue to support demand for optical products and hearing aids. Internationally, similar trends in population and lifestyle dynamics are also increasing demand for optical products and hearing aids. - _Technology._ Sales are affected by the availability of technologically innovative products in our product range due to customer demand for the latest technology in optical products. In past decades, there have been significant advances in technology, which have had a positive impact on average basket size. Progressive lenses, photochromatic lenses (i.e., which darken automatically when exposed to sunlight and fade to clear lenses when indoors), polycarbonate lenses (thinner, lighter and more impact-resistant than standard plastic lenses), anti-reflective and anti-scratch lens coatings, break-resistant optical frames (designed with flexible joints and materials that allow a greater degree of bending than conventional frames) and new materials used for contact lenses such as silicon hydrogel are examples of the technologically innovative products sought by customers. Notably, we expect that over time, as the general population ages, the increase in the penetration rate of progressive lenses will lead to an increase in the average basket for optical products. - _Overall economic conditions. As revenue is linked to end customers’ expenditure, the network’s optical product sales have historically been affected by overall macroeconomic conditions and the resulting effects on household consumption, while showing strong resilience as a health-care related expense. These effects may be more significant in countries where the level of reimbursement by insurance systems is low or non-existent, which is the case for most of the markets in which we operate, except France, our largest market. In certain instances, customers have responded to the uncertainty and volatility stemming from macroeconomic conditions by delaying their spending on optical products, rather than simply renouncing to the expense, which explains the longer product renewal cycle observed during challenging economic times. Generally, the renewal cycle for optical products decreases when overall economic conditions start to improve, leading to positive like-for-like network sales growth. Hearing aid product sales are also influenced by prices, as these products were only partially reimbursed in France (although at a lower rate than for optical products) prior to the reforms associated with 100% Santé, and are not reimbursed at all in Spain. - _Regulatory environment. Changes in the regulatory environment impact sales (see “Regulation”). This is especially the case in France, where certain regulatory developments have in the past facilitated access to optical products by reducing administrative barriers to optical prescriptions (see “Regulation”). For a discussion of recent changes in the regulatory environment in France, see “Regulation—Regulations governing the French complementary health insurance system”. _Fiscal year ended July 31, 2021_ The Group’s like-for-like network sales grew by 20% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021. ----- _France_ In France, the network recorded growth of 0.2% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021. Optical sales benefitted from a strong recovery, with growth of 3.1% in like-for-like sales compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019. This recovery was present despite the fact that the third wave of the COVID-19 pandemic had a strong impact on the business at the start of calendar year 2021, a period during which approximately 150 of our stores in shopping centers were forced to close from February to May 2021. As a result of having a strong presence in shopping centers, the COVID-19 pandemic had a greater impact on our business compared to independent stores that were not operating in shopping centers and therefore were not forced to close. As a consequence of such closures, ALAIN AFFELOU sales grew by 19.3%, slightly below the estimation of GfK (20.0%) and Observatoire de l’Optique (21.5%), which was attenuated by the expansion of the store count mentioned above. One important aspect of the COVID-19 pandemic was the impact on discretionary sales. Sales of sunglasses and contact lenses were deeply impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, more contact lens wearers shifted to online purchases, and the sunglasses segment was likely affected by the lack of tourists and lower traffic in certain shopping areas, such as large shopping centers. For instance, the market experienced a 7.5% decline in sunglasses sales during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021, compared to the same period two years prior. The decline for ALAIN AFFELOU was larger due to its presence in tourist areas and large shopping centers. Our discount banner showed a slightly better performance compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019, as the stores base included a lower presence in tourist areas and large shopping centers. Finally, like-for-like sales for the hearing aid network grew by 52.8% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021, and 17.3% compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019, at consistent levels with the strong increase of the market, after the launch of the final phase of 100% Santé. _Spain_ Network sales increased by 14.5% on a like-for-like basis during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021. As was the case in France, sales rebounded strongly since June and July 2020, apart from slowdowns observed during new episodes of restrictive measures. As in France, discretionary sales were affected by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. For instance, our network activity lost 35% of sunglasses sales compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019 in line with the market (a decrease of 36.7%). As discretionary sales have a higher weight in Spain than in France, the outcome on the total market is a lower recovery (19.1% for the fiscal year). The market still lagged behind the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019 (negative 2.3% compared to negative 0.4% for our optical sales in Spain). _Other countries_ Network sales in the Other countries segment increased by 22.0% on a like-for-like basis during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to a recovery in network sales in Belgium and Switzerland. _Fiscal year ended July 31, 2022_ The Group’s network like-for-like sales grew by 0.3% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. _France_ In France, the network sales grew by 0.2% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Sales in the last quarter were impacted by the war in Ukraine and a drop in consumption in all retail activities in France during spring 2022. The comparison on the fiscal year at our historical optical network still showed a positive evolution of 2.7% compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019. On the whole, our optical network decreased by 0.1% in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022, but still outperformed the French market which decreased by 1.0%, as estimated by Xerfi-Observatoire l’optique. More recent trends in France in August and September resulted in positive trends for our ----- Group. Structural factors for our sector, such as unemployment rates and consumption trends remained solid in France, with clear support from the Government, including purchasing power measures initiated during summer 2022. During this period we carefully monitored the evolution of our activity in both optical and hearing aid activities, with a specific focus on traffic and volumes, especially in shopping centers and large traffic areas. We also carefully observed market trends and consumer behavior in our sector so that if there was a deterioration of consumption by our customers we could adequately respond with appropriate commercial offers and products; though sales in our network were positively oriented through the end of September. _Spain_ In Spain, network sales decreased by 0.5% during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Despite a difficult environment with a greater impact on our activity due to a large proportion of discretionary sales in Spain, our performance was almost stable during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. In addition, our historical banner experienced growth compared to the pre-COVID-19 pandemic periods, with a positive evolution of 0.7% in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 compared to the fiscal year ended July 31, 2019. _Other countries_ Network sales in the Other countries segment increased by 3.7% on a like-for-like basis during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Our Belgium area recorded a decrease of 1.2% in like-for-like sales for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022, but still represented high single-digit growth compared to the same period pre-COVID-19. Our Swiss area continued to show a strong performance and grew by 11.6%. In addition to the positive environment in Switzerland and the strong dynamism of our franchisees, locally, our like-for-like sales recorded a technical positive impact linked to the rise of the Swiss franc versus the euro, accounting for approximately 6.0% of the like-for-like total growth. _Fiscal year ended July 31, 2023_ The Group’s network like-for-like sales increased by 4.4% in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. _France_ In France, network sales increased by 3.8% in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. Sales continued to show solid growth, despite the continued decline in our hearing aids business, which impacted the fiscal year in line with trends in the market after rapid volume growth post-2021 following regulatory changes making hearing aids more affordable. During the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, our optical business recorded like-for-like 5.4% growth compared to 4.0% in the overall market for the same full-year period, as reported by Xerfi-Observatoire l’optique. We believe this growth was due to structural factors, such as: (i) historically low unemployment rates, (ii) strong consumption trends in France, and (iii) a catch-up effect after the COVID-19 pandemic, as many of our customers postponed their glasses purchases (instead of foregoing these purchases altogether). In addition, we believe ALAIN AFFLELOU outperformed the market and improved its commercial performance over the last five fiscal years through a series of initiatives such as Magic clips now suitable for almost all of our exclusive collections and our teleophthalmology innovation which was available in 100 stores as at July 31, 2023. Customer surveys (such as Gallileo’s 2023 survey) continue to show our strong brand awareness, and a positive and improving image of our brand, positioning ourselves on the podium of leading brands in our sector. _Spain_ In Spain, network sales increased by 7.9% on a like-for-like basis during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. We believe, as is the case in France, that the optical business benefitted from a catch-up effect after the COVID-19 pandemic, as supported by GfK, reporting a total market growth of 4.1% during the prior fiscal year, despite a difficult environment with a greater impact on our activity due to a large proportion of discretionary sales in Spain. As is the case in France, our historical banner registered ----- strong growth, significantly outperforming the market. In addition, we believe that in Spain we benefitted from the rapid growth of our hearing aids business offering strong synergies with our optical business. _Other countries_ Network sales in the Other countries segment increased by 2.9% on a like-for-like basis during the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. Our Belgium area recorded a slight growth of 0.8% in like-for-like sales for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, recovering from a more difficult market environment in the 2022 calendar year. Conversely, our Swiss area slowed down to a total growth of 4.7% in like-for-like sales after a growth of 11.6% in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. In the other countries, we observed continued growth at our Portuguese network, with like-for-like performance of 5.7% throughout the fiscal year, with a combination of positive sector orientation, and the optimization of our network (reflecting a solid balance of directly-owned stores and renewed franchisee partners). _Nine months ended April 30, 2024_ Our like-for-like network sales increased by 3.8% during the nine months ended April 30, 2024. This solid performance was obtained despite lower sales as a result of the Easter holiday, especially in Spain during the month of March. Positive performance of our like-for-like sales gives us confidence for the coming months, as we expect that May and June will benefit from our communication campaign, which started in April and lasted until the beginning of June, covering both of our optical and hearing aid businesses. _France_ Our like-for-like network sales increased by 3.4% during the nine months ended April 30, 2024. This increase was due to the solid performance of our optical business as a result of initiatives such as our _Magic collection and the teleophthalmology solution, and was partly offset by like-for-like sales of our_ hearing aid business which broke even due to the slowdown following the _100% Santé_ regulation settlement in 2021. _Spain_ In Spain, like-for-like network sales increased by 5.7% during the nine months ended April 30, 2024. This was primarily due to like-for-like sales of our hearing aid business increasing by 11.2% as a result of the positive impetus of the optical and hearing aid businesses combination, which was partly offset by a negative performance in March as a result of the Easter holiday. _Other countries_ Like-for-like network sales in our Other countries segment increased by 3.6% during the nine months ended April 30, 2024, primarily due to growth of 6.2% in Belgium and 4.5% in Switzerland. The rest of our Other countries geographical areas were mainly marked by difficulties as a consequence of the political troubles in regions such as the Middle East.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors affecting the comparability of our results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Changes in our scope of consolidation
Subsubsection Text: We consummate acquisitions from time to time to take advantage of opportunities to increase our market share in existing markets or to enter adjacent geographies or complementary markets. Our management believes that acquisitions enhance the benefits of scale in our industry, particularly with respect to purchasing power, inventory management and logistics as well as general operational synergies. We typically seek synergies from acquisitions relating to the geographical coverage and density of our store network, supplier relationships and product offerings that allow us to expand our ----- offering to both franchisees and end-customers, distribution capabilities (for example, with respect to e-commerce platforms) and general and administrative costs, among others. Following our decision to progressively discontinue our Optical Discount brand, which resulted in a reduction to 22 stores bearing the Optical Discount banner as at July 31, 2023, Optical Discount activities (which we plan to progressively terminate by the end of 2024) are treated as discontinued operations in the audited consolidated financial statements for our fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 and our unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial information for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. For comparison purposes, the comparative income statement and statement of cash flows columns setting forth our financial information for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 and the nine months ended April 30, 2023 were restated with Optical Discount as discontinued operations. No restatement of balance sheet information was performed, in accordance with IFRS 5. In contrast, the discussion of our results of operations for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 and 2022 presented in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” corresponds to the audited consolidated income statement information included in the relevant financial statements and therefore includes Optical Discount’s contribution. For further information, see note 4.3.1 to the Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In assessing the performance of our business, our management considers a variety of performance and financial measures. The key measures for determining how our business is performing are like-for-like network sales growth (as discussed above under “—Key factors affecting our results of _operations—Like-for-like network sales growth”), store count (as discussed above under “—Key factors_ affecting our results of operations—Expansion of store network”)_ and Adjusted EBITDA. Such indicators are not recognized measures of financial performance under IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and _Other Information—Other Financial Measures” and “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial Information” for a reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA to_ operating income from ordinary activities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Including Optical Discount. The graph below shows the evolution of our Adjusted EBITDA from the third quarter of the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to July 31, 2024: ----- _Source: Company information._ (1) Excluding Optical Discount. (2) Reported Adjusted EBITDA for quarter three of the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 (including Optical Discount) was €19.8 million (resulting in a 10.5% margin on network sales including Optical Discount) and reported Adjusted EBITDA for quarter three of the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 (including Optical Discount) was €24.4 million (resulting in a 11.5% margin on network sales including Optical Discount). The Group’s Adjusted EBITDA increased by €6.2 million, or 6.2%, to €106.9 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 (compared to €100.7 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021). This increase is mainly linked to the growth of our network activity in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 compared to the prior fiscal year. Growing synergies with the hearing aids business, economies of scale at our optical franchise business in mature areas, and finally, a positive evolution at our DOS structure, also allowed our profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA to significantly offset the slight decline of network sales for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Adjusted EBITDA increased by €7.5 million, or 7.0%, to €114.4 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 (compared to €106.9 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022). The increase was linked to network sales growth. Apart from our hearing aids business and directly-owned stores in France, all of our stores generated a growth in Adjusted EBITDA, replicating the strong dynamism of our network sales. ----- Adjusted EBITDA increased by €3.2 million, from €83.0 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2023 to €86.1 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2024, which was driven by strong sales at our historical banner in most geographical areas compared to the prior comparable period. Following our communication campaign which started in April, our communication revenues started to catch up from the prior quarters but still lagged behind as at the end of April 30, 2024. _France_ Adjusted EBITDA generated in France increased by €6.9 million, or 8.5%, from €81.0 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to €87.9 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. The growth in our profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA in France was also partly linked to the strong evolution of our directly-owned structure, benefitting from sound performances of the two perimeters acquired during the prior fiscal year. While the franchisor performance was attenuated in the last quarter by the decline of 3.0% in network sales, our franchise business reported a satisfactory performance on the full year due to the overall network sales evolution of a 1.4% increase, together with well-managed operating costs, economies of scale in the optical business, and an improvement of our profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA in the hearing aids business at almost 5.0% of network sales. On the whole, our Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of network sales in France reached a peak at 13.2% compared to 12.3%, for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021. Adjusted EBITDA generated in France increased by €4.7 million or 5.3%, from €87.9 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 to €92.6 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. The growth in profitability in France as measured by Adjusted EBITDA was aligned with our growth in network sales by 5.0% across the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. The profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA at our optical business benefitted from economies of scale, while our hearing aid business was impacted by the continued slowdown of the whole sector after its dramatic growth in 2021 following the implementation of _100% Santé. Our directly-owned stores also showed a decline in profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA due to the inflation slightly impacting our gross margin and our personnel costs. As aforementioned, we have started to restructure and reduce our directly-owned stores portfolio, with an organization giving more autonomy to store managers with a lighter headquarters structure, in accordance with the aim of enabling them to become franchisees. Adjusted EBITDA generated in France represented €70.5 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2024, compared to €67.9 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2023. Our Adjusted EBITDA benefitted from the strong network activity at our historical optical banner and the catch-up of our revenue generated from communication campaigns that started in April. The profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA of our French optical network stands at record high levels benefitting from economies of scale while continuing to expand regularly. On the other hand, our profitability growth as measured by Adjusted EBITDA was attenuated by a decline at our directly-owned stores, linked to a lower performance of existing stores and the continued reduction of its perimeter. Finally, our hearing aid business reported an improvement of its profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA following the recovery of the network sales growth in recent months. _Spain_ Adjusted EBITDA generated in Spain decreased by €0.8 million, or 4.9%, from €16.3 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to €15.5 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. The decrease is linked to the loss of €1.1 million at our hearing aid business, which mainly consisted of communication campaigns to relaunch this activity locally. In Spain, on the whole and on a full-year basis, our Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of network sales stood at 12.1%, very close to the level of 13.2% in France. Adjusted EBITDA generated in Spain increased by €2.3 million, or 14.8%, from €15.5 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 to €17.8 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. The increase tracked the strength of our network performance, while we recorded lower losses at our hearing aid business than the prior year (losses were reduced by €0.4 million, following the ramp-up of our network, ----- which reached €7.8 million of sales during the fiscal year, compared to €4.0 million a year before). As a consequence, our profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA in Spain continued to grow, reaching 12.6% of network sales on a full-year basis, at a level close to France, which stood at 13.9% over the same period. Adjusted EBITDA generated in Spain increased by €0.7 million from €12.4 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2023, compared to €13.1 million for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. This increase is primarily due to the strong performance of the optical business. On the other side, our directly-owned stores perimeter reported a decline in profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA resulting from a slight decline in our gross margin as a percentage of sales, and higher external charges and personnel costs, in a context of stagnating sales in recent months. Finally, the continued rise of our hearing aid activity resulted in a significant growth of its profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA with a gain of €0.4 million in the nine months ended April 30, 2024, compared to the prior year, allowing us to almost break even. _Other countries_ Adjusted EBITDA generated in the Other countries segment increased by €0.1 million, from €3.4 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2021 to €3.5 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022. Belgium accounted for close to half of our profitability, as measured by Adjusted EBITDA, at 5.8% of network sales, for the fiscal year. Adjusted EBITDA generated in the Other countries segment increased by €0.5 million, from €3.5 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 to €4.0 million for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. Belgium and Switzerland continued to represent a large part of our profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA in this area, with a mature network in the French-speaking regions of those countries. Adjusted EBITDA generated in the Other Countries segment decreased to €2.5 million during the nine months ended April 30, 2024, compared to €2.6 million during the nine months ended April 30, 2023. The slight decline in profitability as measured by Adjusted EBITDA of this geographical segment is mainly linked to the aforementioned schedule of our communications campaign, with a catch-up starting in April.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue comprises network sales revenue and network purchases revenue, as well as revenue from direct sales to end customers as part of our directly-owned stores business (see “—Overview” for a detailed description of our different sources of revenue). We charge our subsidiaries operating directly-owned stores similar fees as those charged to our franchisees. These expenses are later eliminated on consolidation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Cost of purchases refers primarily to purchases of goods from suppliers and includes communications expenses, mainly for advertising campaigns in various media. Purchases of bought-in goods refers to purchases of exclusive products, mainly as part of the trading activity, and purchases of goods resold to stores in the network through our central purchasing units and frames and sunglasses trading ----- subsidiary. Purchases from suppliers also includes purchases of bought-in goods made by directly-owned stores from suppliers and through our central purchasing units (in which case the purchases are eliminated on consolidation) that are sold to end customers. We neither operate nor own any manufacturing facilities. Consequently, our products are manufactured by independent third parties.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Wages and salaries including social security contributions
Subsubsection Text: Wages and salaries including social security contributions mainly comprises wages and salaries. It also comprises social security contributions (principally related to France), expenses related to profit-sharing schemes and tax income related to the Crédit d’impôt pour la compétitivité et l’emploi (“CICE”) and the _Crédit d’Impôt Recherche (“CIR”). Wages and salaries including social security contributions includes_ employees of our directly-owned stores and central services, and contributions to profit-sharing and employee incentive schemes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other purchases and external expenses mainly covers rental fees and related costs, outsourcing fees and miscellaneous services, maintenance and repair expenses, and other purchases. Rental fees are mainly composed of rent in respect of directly-owned stores, and, to a lesser extent, the rental costs associated with our offices. Other expenses mainly comprise payments for various third-party services, such as outsourcing of information systems, temporary workers, and different expenses linked to the operation of stores (such as information technology or energy), management fees paid to certain shareholders, travel expenses, shipping and telecommunications expenses, and certain banking services.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Duties and taxes other than income tax
Subsubsection Text: Duties and taxes other than income tax includes taxes on salaries (mainly training taxes), social construction tax (contribution to social housing), social solidarity contribution (contribution sociale de _solidarité des sociétés, “C3S”), which is based on a percentage of net sales, and real property tax,_ including the Cotisation Foncière des Entreprises (“CFE”) and tax on commercial areas (taxe sur les _surfaces commerciales – TASCOM). In Spain, duties and taxes other than income mainly includes_ property tax (impuesto sobre bienes immeubles – IBI). In the Other countries segment, they mainly include customs duties related to the trading activity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortization and impairment relates to regular depreciation and amortization of current and non-current assets and provisions for impairment. Depreciation, amortization and impairment includes the following items: - depreciation of property, plant and equipment and right-of-use assets, mainly pertaining to directly-owned stores, in connection with the refurbishment of stores or the opening of new stores; - amortization of intangible assets with determinable useful lives, such as intellectual property rights (other than our trademarks), and other information technology investments; and - changes in provisions for current assets, particularly receivables, changes in inventories, changes in provisions for third-party and franchisee expenses, changes in provisions for litigation, changes in provisions for retirement benefits, changes in provisions for franchisee risks, such as the risk of goods being returned as part of our trading activities, and changes in provisions for retirement benefits. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating income from ordinary activities represents revenue generated by us, net of all recurring operating expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other non-recurring operating items includes other items in the income statement that, due to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as part of our ordinary activities. These items primarily include: (i) proceeds from disposals of assets; (ii) reversal of, and charges to, exceptional provisions related to the impairment of assets, such as goodwill, trademarks and business and leasehold rights; (iii) provisions to cover expenses relating to litigation proceedings and provisions relating to rental payments on vacant premises; and (iv) costs incurred from the acquisition of new entities, or any other non-recurring income or expenses, that we present on a separate line to facilitate the reader’s understanding of recurring operating performance and provide him/her with useful information to identify trends in the Issuer’s financial performance.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating profit represents operating income from ordinary activities, net of other non-recurring operating items.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Net financial income/(expense) consists of financial income less gross borrowing costs and other financial expenses. Financial income consists of income from other financial assets, other financial income and reversals of financial provisions, and interest on vendor loans granted to franchisees and interest charged to franchisees in the event of late payments. Gross borrowing costs include (i) interest on the convertible bonds, senior secured bonds and senior subordinated bonds, and (ii) financial expense on lease liabilities and other financial expenses. Financial expense mainly includes: (i) financial provisions, (ii) other financial expense IFRS 16 and (iii) miscellaneous financial expenses or income, including foreign exchange differences.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net income/(expense) before tax of consolidated companies
Subsubsection Text: Net income/(expense) before tax of consolidated companies comprises operating profit and net financial income/(expense).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Tax income/(expense) includes current taxes and deferred taxes. Current taxes corresponds to the income tax due, which is calculated using the tax rate in effect on the record date, adjusted for income tax payable in respect of prior years. Tax income/(expense) also includes the corporate value added tax (cotisation sur la valeur ajoutée des entreprises, the “CVAE”). It excludes the taxes presented within other operating income and expenses. The deferred tax amount shows the impact of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities of consolidated companies and their respective taxable amounts that are used in determining the taxable profit of future periods by applying the tax rates in effect on the record date. -----
