Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Off-balance sheet commitments of the Issuer are described in note 6.6.1 to the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. No significant changes in off-balance sheet commitments are to be noted as of April 30, 2024. As of the Issue Date, the Issuer’s assets will consist largely of its direct and indirect interest in the share capital of 3ABOD, the 3AB Optique Développement Proceeds Loan and the Alain Afflelou Franchiseur Proceeds Loan and its liabilities will be limited to the Notes, and guarantees under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. The Issuer will not have any material off-balance sheet commitments, other contingent liabilities or contractual commitments. Secured loans are part of our overall borrowing capacity. For such operations, we are involved in these transactions in our capacity as guarantor to these banks for the financing they provide to franchisees in the proportion of 100% of each application for financing, limited in certain cases to a maximum percentage (e.g. 30%) contractually agreed for each facility. We have access to uncommitted discount receivables lines (cessions Dailly) for an amount of approximately €43.0 million, with a group of commercial banks. These lines give us capacity to borrow against receivables from franchisees that mature at a maximum of 45 days and are on a recourse basis. These lines are generally used for working capital purposes for short periods, generally for intra-month requirements. In the nine-month period ended April 30, 2024, we did not utilize these lines. See “Description of Certain Other Indebtedness and Other Arrangements—Assignment of accounts _receivable”._ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosures about market risk
Subsubsection Text: Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. We face foreign exchange risks to the extent that most of our revenue is in euros while we source most of our frames and sunglasses from a Chinese intermediary agent, as discussed above, on the basis of a price list denominated in U.S. dollars. Although our current arrangements with our Chinese intermediary agent use a fixed exchange rate between euros and U.S. dollars for certain purchases, this rate could change or cease to be fixed, in which case a sustained appreciation of the U.S. dollar against the euro may lead to an increase in prices we pay for products that we may not necessarily be able to pass on, whether partially or entirely, to our franchisees or end customers. In addition, our network works with suppliers who, although their merchandise is billed in euros, are themselves subject to fluctuations in exchange rates, in particular between euros and U.S. dollars.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosures about market risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to interest rate fluctuations as certain of our indebtedness bears interest rates at floating rates that could increase, increasing our debt service obligations. Borrowings under the New Revolving Credit Facility will bear interest indexed to the Euro Interbank Offered Rate (“EURIBOR”), adjusted periodically, plus a margin for drawings in euro, may increase significantly in the future, resulting in additional interest expense for us, reducing the cash available to deploy for investments and limiting our ability to service our indebtedness.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosures about market risk
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer’s financial liabilities mainly include borrowings and trade, security deposits and other debts. As of April 30, 2024, security deposits as defined in the Note 6.2.7.1 to the unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements of the Issuer as of and for the nine months ended April 30, 2024 were €1,262 thousand and as of May 31, 2024, the security deposits were below the amount of €1.3 million. These liabilities may expose us to liquidity risk in the event of early repayment or short maturity. In order to manage our liquidity risk, we rely on cash on hand and additionally contracts revolving credit or bank facilities for an appropriate amount and maturity to ensure that we have adequate available funds to meet our commitments with a large range of financial institutions. The Group periodically reviews the assumptions of its multi-year business plan. The development and net cash flow generation objectives (after investment and financing operations) have been reviewed in this context and take into account the changing interest rate environment. We had cash and cash equivalents of €105.0 million as of April 30, 2024 and €75.2 million as of July 31, 2023, respectively, and €55.3 million as of July 31, 2022. The Existing Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, April 30, 2024 and July 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The discussion and analysis of the Issuer’s financial condition and results of operations are based upon the Issuer’s consolidated financial statements, which were prepared in accordance with IFRS as of the date of preparation of the financial statements, including the International Accounting Standards (“IAS”) and IFRS standards and the International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee (“IFRIC”) interpretations. The preparation of this financial information requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities. We believe that the estimates, assumptions and judgments involved in the accounting policies described below have the greatest potential impact on the Issuer’s financial information, so we consider these to be our critical accounting policies. Due to the uncertainty inherent in these matters, actual results could differ from the estimates we use in applying the critical accounting policies described below. For more information, see note 4.4, note 4.3, and note ----- 4.3 to the Issuer’s consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, 2022, and 2021, respectively, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and intangible assets (including trademarks) arise in connection with acquisitions. We do not amortize goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives. Intangible assets with finite lives are amortized on a straight-line basis over the assets’ respective useful lives. Goodwill is tested for impairment at least annually, at year end, using the method described in the notes to the Issuer’s consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The outcome of such an assessment is subjective, and the result sensitive to the assumed future cash flows to be generated by the cash-generating units or assets and discount rates applied in calculating the value in use. Any impairment arising is charged to the income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We offer our employees retirement plans and other long-term benefits in accordance with regulations and market practices in France and Spain. We account for our defined benefit plans in accordance with IAS 19 “Employee benefits”. Accounting for retirement benefit plans requires us to make assumptions including, but not limited to, discount rates, rates of inflation, retirement age and life expectancies. The use of different assumptions could have a material effect on the accounting values of the relevant assets and liabilities which could result in a material change to the cost of such liabilities as recognized in the income statement over time. These assumptions are subject to periodic review.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that it is regarded as probable that the deductible temporary differences can be realized. The probability that we are able to realize such differences is based on fiscal forecasts drawn up for the tax consolidation group. We estimate deferred tax assets as well as expectations regarding the manner and timing of recovery of the related assets. Changes in these estimates may affect the amount of deferred tax liabilities or the valuation of deferred tax assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We record provisions for liabilities when we have a current obligation (legal or implied) resulting from a past event; it is likely that an outflow of resources representative of economic benefits will be necessary in order to clear the obligation; and the amount of the obligation can be estimated reliably. The provisions are determined and updated based on assumptions made by us at each reporting date. When the impact is significant, we discount provisions based on a discount rate that reflects the risk-free interest rate and the risks specific to the asset. Due to the uncertainty inherent in these matters, actual results could differ from the estimates on which these provisions are based.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Communication fees collected from stores in our network on a monthly and quarterly basis are recognized as revenue generated by such fees when advertising expenses or communication fees are effectively incurred, for instance in connection with the launch of an advertising campaign. Revenues are recorded in proportion to expenses and the margin that we intend to make on the advertising campaign. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Valuation of inventories requires the exercise of judgement, particularly with regard to impairment, as prospective inventory turnover rates are used in such valuation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis of the Issuer’s financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”. The following discussion should also be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, the Issuer’s unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements for the nine months ended April 30, 2024, which include the unaudited comparative financial information for the nine months ended April 30, 2023, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and the Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, an English translation of which is included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The Issuer’s consolidated financial statements for the aforementioned periods have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. The Issuer’s unaudited condensed interim consolidated financial statements for the aforementioned period have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34, the standard of IFRS as adopted by the European Union applicable to interim financial statements. The Issuer’s unaudited consolidated financial statements for the nine months ended April 30, 2024, which include the unaudited comparative financial information for the nine months ended April 30, 2023, were subject to a limited review by Ernst & Young et Autres and Deloitte & Associés, the Issuer’s statutory auditors for such period, as set forth in their review report included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021 were subject to an audit by Ernst & Young et Autres and Deloitte & Associés, the Issuer’s statutory auditors for such years, as set forth in the free English translation of their audit reports included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. For the consolidated financial statements of the Issuer for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, an English translation of the consolidated financial statements and a free English translation of the auditors’ reports are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Following our decision to progressively discontinue our Optical Discount brand, which resulted in a reduction to 22 stores bearing the Optical Discount banner as at July 31, 2023, Optical Discount activities (which we plan to progressively terminate by the end of 2024) are treated as discontinued operations in the audited consolidated financial statements for our fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 and the interim condensed consolidated financial statements for the nine months ended April 30, 2024. For comparison purposes, the comparative income statement column setting forth our financial information for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2022 and for the nine months ended April 30, 2023 was restated with Optical Discount as discontinued operations. No restatement of balance sheet information was performed, in accordance with IFRS 5. In contrast, the discussion of our results of operations for the fiscal years ended July 31, 2022 and 2021 presented in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” corresponds to the audited consolidated income statement information included in the relevant financial statements and therefore includes Optical Discount’s contribution as continuing operations. For further information, see “—Factors affecting the comparability of our results of operations—Changes in our scope of consolidation” and note 4.3.1 to our audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

The application of IFRS 16 requires the exercise of judgement, particularly with regard to: - the definition of a lease; - the determination of the lease term, which takes into account the exercise of termination or renewal options when the Group is reasonably certain of exercising them; and - the determination of the incremental borrowing rate, which is calculated by taking into account residual lease terms on the date of first application. We conduct a review of our leases on an annual basis to determine whether or not we may terminate or renew such leases. -----

The Optical Products market refers to products addressing vision correction or protection needs, such as optical lenses, frames, contact lenses, sunglasses and ancillary optical accessories (such as care products, cases, cords and chains) which are generally sold across optical stores. As of 2023, the market in France (excluding sales recorded outside of metropolitan France) had a value of €7.4 billion and the market in Spain had a value of €2.4 billion, in each case according to GfK. Optical lenses represent by far the largest share of products sold (approximately 63.0% and 57.0% of the total market sizes in France and Spain, respectively) followed by frames (approximately 25% and 17% of the total market in France and Spain, respectively), sunglasses (approximately 6.0% and 14.0% of the total market in France and Spain, respectively) and contact lenses and care products (approximately 6.0% and 13.0% of the total market in France and Spain, respectively). Optical products are segmented as either (i) healthcare-related prescription products, directly addressing vision impairment and eligible for reimbursement from healthcare insurance providers (representing approximately 86.0% and 94.0% of the market in Spain and France respectively according to GfK) or (ii) non-prescription products (such as sunglasses without optical lenses attached), entirely bought “out-of-pocket” (representing approximately 14.0% and 6.0% of the market in Spain and France respectively according to GfK) which are generally products that are not being processed (either assembled or transformed, as it is the case for lenses) and are sold as is. ----- _Source: GfK._

Subsubsection Title: Prescription Optical Products – Approximately €9.0 Billion Market Size (France and Spain)
Subsubsection Text: Prescription optical products (“Prescription Optical Products”) are non-discretionary healthcare products which include (i) optical lenses, (ii) frames and (iii) contact lenses and care products. Typically prescribed by ophthalmologists, optometrists, orthoptist or opticians (depending on countries), following eye tests, Prescription Optical Products fall within the reimbursement scope of public healthcare systems or private insurance (see “Industry—Market Drivers”). In France, historically, only ophthalmologists were authorized to perform eye tests and issue prescriptions with a three to five-year validity period depending on ages (three years for people older than 42 years and five years for people between 16 and 42). As part of the _100% Santé regulation applicable as of January 2021 (described below under “Market Drivers”), which amongst other measures was intended to address shortages of ophthalmologists, opticians now have the ability to perform eye tests and adapt, if necessary, ophthalmologist prescriptions. We believe this regulation supports sales of Prescription Optical Products in France. In Spain, opticians and optometrists are able to perform eye tests and write prescriptions, including through teleconsultations which, combined with the shortage of ophthalmologists (similarly to France), creates opportunities for opticians. For further information concerning the regulations governing the optical products and hearing aid market in France and Spain, see “Regulation—France—Regulations governing the optical products and hearing _aid _markets in France” and “Regulation—Spain—Regulations governing the optical products and hearing aid markets in Spain”._ Functionality, comfort and aesthetics are the key factors influencing a customer’s decision when selecting Prescription Optical Products. ----- _Source: Company Information (analysis above limited to France). Optical Lenses_ Optical lenses (also called “corrective lenses”) fall into two main categories of products: (i) _unifocal _lenses (single vision lenses) and (ii) multifocal lenses addressing several correction regions (including,_ for instance, bifocals or progressive lenses). The market for corrective lenses has grown and developed considerably over the years, fueled by the emergence of technologies such as digital surfacing (allowing to produce tailor-made lenses, including more technically demanding progressive lenses). Essilor-Luxottica, Carl Zeiss Vision and Hoya are the leading suppliers of corrective lenses. _Frames_ Frames are available in wide ranges of materials, styles and brands. They are usually adapted to suit wearers and may feature useful add-ons such as flexible spring hinges. Many customers consider glasses to be fashion accessories in addition to their functional purpose. Aesthetics and brand name are therefore considered key decision factors when customers make the decision to purchase frames. The market for frame manufacturing, which consists of a large number of medium-sized players, is highly fragmented and competitive. However, a few groups including EssilorLuxottica, Safilo Kering-Eyewear (part of Kering Group), Thélios (part of LVMH) and Marcolin are considered the leaders in this market, in particular for luxury brands. _Contact Lenses and Care Solutions_ Contact lenses can be unifocal or multifocal (i.e., similar to corrective lenses). Further, contact lenses can be soft, rigid or hybrid. Rigid contact lenses are generally more expensive than soft contact lenses (with up to single usage, or daily use) because they may be used for long periods without replacement. Contact lenses also require certain care products, such as daily or weekly cleaning solutions. ----- Contact lenses present customers with an alternative to wearing glasses. Consequently, customers who wear contact lenses typically also own at least one pair of glasses to regularly or occasionally replace their contact lenses. Contact lenses are typically sold, not only in brick and mortar opticians, but also through e-commerce and pharmacies (as these products can automatically be renewed without necessarily being seen before by an optician). See “Competitive Landscape”. The market for the manufacturing of contact lenses is led by three U.S. manufacturers (Johnson & Johnson, Bausch & Lomb and Coopervision) and one Swiss manufacturer (Alcon-Ciba).

The non-prescription optical products category consists primarily of sunglasses, which are both used as a protection and fashion item, explaining the particularly high market penetration rate. Leading manufacturers of sunglasses are the same as in the frames segment. Other products in this category include, for instance, ready-readers, protective or care products (notably for contact lenses) or accessories cases, cord and chains, etc. along with rather niche cosmetic products and other fashion items (such as binoculars). Those products are typically bought through a variety of channels, including department stores, clothing or fashion stores, grocery stores and generalist, pure-play e-commerce websites, as well as brick and mortar opticians.

The market for Hearing Aids refers to products addressing hearing conditions exclusively through aid devices (i.e., does not include hearing implants). Healthcare-related hearing aid products benefit from significant reimbursement and regulatory backing in France (but limited in Spain). In 2023, the market in France had a value of €2.0 billion and the market in Spain had a value of €0.6 billion (according to Xerfi and Sra.Modne) with particularly strong tailwinds and growing penetration of hearing aids products, following introduction of the _100% Santé_ regulation in France (see “Market _Development”)._ The size of the addressable population for hearing aid products remains smaller compared to optical products. The population with hearing impairment is estimated to be approximately 10.0% in France and Spain (according to EuroTrak) compared to an estimated 68.0% to 79.0% for vision impairment in France (according to Xerfi). Significant untapped potential remains, however, in a market characterized by lower penetration rates (approximately 39.0% to 46.0% of the self-declared hearing impaired population in Spain and France; according to EuroTrak) in comparison to optical products. While the fundamental components of hearing aids are the same, the specific components used across different hearing aids can vary significantly. The cost of a high-end hearing aid can be many times the price of a low-end hearing aid. Such cost differences are generally driven by the device’s software, components and functionality. Hearing aid manufacturers are highly concentrated, with the top six hearing aid manufacturers accounting for approximately 90.0% of the market (Sivantos (Siemens)/Widex, Sonova, William Demant, GN Resound, and Starkey). There is a risk of additional competition as companies such as ----- Apple may enter this specific market, particularly with the growing convergence between headphones and related technologies.

One of the main drivers of market growth is the growing prevalence of hearing and vision conditions, directly linked to structurally ageing (older segments of the population register higher rates of visual anomalies) and growing populations, along with evolving lifestyles. In terms of ageing, hearing and vision begin to deteriorate progressively from ages 40 to 45 with more serious impairments, such as presbycusis (hearing) or presbyopia (vision), becoming more common and irreversible with ageing. This is evidenced by the higher penetration rate of optical products amongst older age groups (94.0% to 97.0% for the French population aged 65 and older have vision impairments compared to 33.0% to 52.0% for the French population aged between 15 and 24) with a similar pattern for hearing aid products (approximately 33.0% of the French population aged 74 and older have hearing loss compared to approximately 3.0% for the French population aged between 15 and 24 according to DREES and Xerfi). As such, as the population ages and the population aged 45 and older in France and Spain becomes more numerous, the addressable market is expected to grow both in terms of volume and prices, with the latter reflecting the increasing need of older people for more expensive vision or hearing solutions, such as progressive lenses that are twice as expensive than simpler unifocals. Moreover, continuous demographic growth in France and Spain combined with evolving lifestyle choices, such as increasing screen time or extensive use of headphones, support a higher prevalence of vision and hearing impairments even at younger ages, as indicated by the below graphs. _Sources: Xerfi and DREES._ ----- _Source: EuroTrak France 2022._

The optical and hearing aid products markets are characterized by steady repurchase and replacement cycles across both France and Spain (an average estimate of 2.8 years from 2015 to 2021 in France according to a report prepared by Advancy in 2022, and an average estimate of 4.2 years from 2015 to 2021 in Spain for optical products according to the same report, and an estimated five years for hearing aid products in France according to Xerfi) linked to numerous factors such as loss or damage, wear and tear, reimbursement cycles (where applicable), technological improvements and, for optical products specifically, vision changes and fashion trends (especially for frames and sunglasses). Consumers also typically own more than one pair of glasses (a trend referred as “multi-possession”) including consumers who primarily use contact lenses.

Subsubsection Title: Social Drivers, Health, Lifestyle and Macroeconomics
Subsubsection Text: Certain social drivers underpin the continuous growth of the hearing aid and optical products markets. For hearing aids, social drivers include (i) increased social acceptance of these products (absence of stigmatization) and (ii) urbanization and noise pollution. For optical products, social drivers include higher levels of (i) people attending schools and universities, (ii) skilled and technical jobs, (iii) use of computers and similar devices (including uptake on blue-light blocking technology), (iv) awareness of eye protection from sun exposure, (v) demand for multiple glasses and (vi) focus on health and wellness (i.e. need to maintain good eyesight).

Regulations and reimbursement frameworks have been highly contributive to generating higher demand for our products however at varying levels depending on countries with a relatively better framework in France compared to Spain. _Optical Products_ Reimbursement Frameworks In France, Prescription Optical Products benefit from high reimbursement levels through both a public (“French Social Security”) and private (“OCAMs”) healthcare insurance mix and so these products have limited out-of-pocket costs for customers, supporting a very resilient market by nature. Since the implementation of the Accord National Interprofessionnel (“ANI”), requiring companies to offer complementary and private insurance to employees (offering more generous reimbursements), average ----- out-of-pocket costs have decreased to approximately 23.0% in 2019 compared to approximately 36.0% in 2009 (according to Advancy). Remaining costs are typically covered by French Social Security for (up to approximately 5.0%) and by complementary private healthcare insurance (OCAM) (up to approximately 73.0%). With the 100% Santé reform, we believe that the average out-of-pocket costs for end-customers will continue to stand at a limited proportion of the total expense, including the requirement to opticians to offer a minimum number of so-called “Class A” products that are capped at a specific price to allow no out-of-pocket costs for end-customers. Following the 100% Santé reform, opticians are now required to offer a minimum of 35 frame models for adults, and 20 frame models for children, at €30.0 or less, with lenses ranging between €32.50 and €170.0. More expensive products, so-called “Class B”, products bear no constraints and allow customers more freedom of choice albeit limiting frame reimbursements, which are capped at €100 compared to €150 before the reform. Approximately 16.0% of glasses sold, fall within the 100% Santé framework. In contrast, Spain is characterized by relatively low coverage of optical costs by the public health system, low enrollment in private insurance and, more generally speaking, a regulatory framework that is not as supportive as in France (for instance no requirement for employers to offer complementary health insurance). Regulation In general, markets where we operate are subject to various types of regulations on the ability to (i) carry out eye tests and write prescriptions, (ii) distribute products (such as the regulation of online tests) or (iii) communicate / market / advertise (restrictions on advertising from health professionals, including opticians). However, regulations on these aspects are becoming more liberal and, if such trends continue, notably on the easing on eye testing restrictions in France (see “Industry—Optical Products Markets”), the market is expected to become increasingly more accessible and therefore beneficial to opticians. _Hearing Aids_ Reimbursement frameworks Given high average prices for hearing aids ranging from less than €1,000 to more than €2,000 according to Arcane, customers’ out-of-pocket expenses have been comparatively higher versus optical products. In France, where device reimbursement is driven by a public and private mix (similar to optical products), out-of-pocket expenses were approximately 50.0% on average in 2019, before the introduction of 100% _Santé regulation, according to Arcane._ The recent changes brought by 100% Santé, which increased reimbursement of hearing aid products up to €950, significantly helped decrease out-of-pocket expenses for customers to an estimated 35% as of 2023 according to Arcane. The reform has since supported strong demand from customers previously deterred from hearing aid products due to their relative high costs – see “—Market _Development”. Between 36.0% and 38.0% of hearing aid equipment sold, fall within the 100% Santé_ framework. In Spain, the reimbursement of hearing aids is more limited as public health insurance does not reimburse these costs and enrollment in complementary health insurance plans is rather low. In countries such as Spain where reimbursement rates are low, the affordability of hearing aids is ----- particularly sensitive (most of the cost being borne by customers), which explains a relatively low penetration rate (in 2022, 46.0% of self-declared hearing impaired population in France with hearing aids compared to 39.0% in Spain according to EuroTrak). According to Arcane, the average price of hearing aids has been stable since 2016, ranging from €1,565 in 2016 to €1,557 in 2023. This stability is partly explained by the change in product mix sold resulting from the 100% Santé reform, with a greater proportion of entry level equipment being sold. Regulation Similarly to Optical Products, the Hearing Aid market is highly regulated, including with respect to the ability to carry out tests, write prescriptions and distribute and promote products. In general, the adoption of hearing aid products is rising as regulatory barriers are decreasing, principally driven by (i) decreasing costs (i.e., improving reimbursement frameworks with the ability to buy equipment with zero out-of-pocket costs in France following the 100% Santé reform in France) and (ii) the liberalization of hiring professionals (the numerus clausus for ENT specialists increased by over 50.0% between 2015 and 2021 in France according to Advancy and more responsibility has been given to mid-level health professions such as nurses, technicians, audiologists, pharmacists, etc.).

The market for optical and hearing products has grown alongside technological innovations, with different dynamics across optical and hearing products. On optical products, technological advances have primarily taken the form of “add-on” supplements (such as multifocal or polarized lenses or blue-light blocking coatings), which favor continuous average selling price increases. In contrast, in hearing, innovations have favored downward pricing pressure by promoting affordability (to penetrate markets) alongside more discreet, comfortable or functional products. Key innovations on optical products include, amongst others, (i) polycarbonate lenses (thinner, lighter and more impact-resistant compared to standard plastic lenses), (ii) break-resistant frames, which allow a greater degree of bending compared to conventional frames, (iii) new materials (i.e., silicon hydrogel) and (iv) general innovations for lenses (progressive, anti-reflective, shock-proof, light-adaptive lenses, scratch-resistant, polarized, ultraviolet-protective or blue-light blocking). In hearing, step improvements in microphone or microchip technologies have led to the introduction of miniature hearing aids, which are virtually invisible, easy to insert and remove and offer better hearing correction. Also, those devices embed growing technologies, that can be used with other electronic devices, such as televisions and mobile phones, adding other applications than hearing improvement.
Market drivers are broadly consistent across addressed verticals, hearing aids and optical products and geographies where ALAIN AFFLELOU is present.

Between 2013 and 2023, the optical product markets in France (excluding sales recorded outside of metropolitan France) and Spain grew at stable pace of over 1.6% and 3.0% per year, respectively, reaching market sizes of €7.4 billion and €2.4 billion, respectively, in 2023, as shown in the graph below. ----- _Sources: SWV and DBK and Company’s estimate for optical market in border countries._ This stable growth was achieved on the back of structurally resilient drivers, despite a number of headwinds impacting markets since 2016 with limited one-off impacts, including (i) the lengthening of replacement cycles to two years by French health insurance providers, (ii) the lowering of reimbursement thresholds following _100% Santé regulation in France, (iii) the COVID-19-induced demand drop in 2020 (market decreasing by 11% year-over-year in France and 17.0% year-over-year in Spain and along with near closure of shops) and (iv) the inflationary environment since 2022. As evidenced by the COVID-19 crisis in 2020, with markets more than recovering the following year, optical products have proven to be resilient and insulated from GDP swings (especially in France where reimbursement frameworks are more favorable) with approximately 86.0% and 94.0% of the market mix in Spain and France being non-discretionary and healthcare-related as shown in the graphs below, given customers generally tend not to defer vision correction once impairment is diagnosed. _Source: GfK._ In terms of average selling price and volume mix, the market has been characterized by rather flat average selling price growth and strong volume increases. A number of trends have exerted downward pressure on average selling price, including (i) promotions and rebates, (ii) an increase in low-price products (marketed by large retailers), (iii) the rise of closed networks or so called mutualists (see “— Competitive Landscape”)_ with preferred tariffs and (iv) regulatory changes (notably in France with 100% _Santé), which were largely compensated by positive product mix evolution, notably through_ technological advances, driving average selling prices higher (multifocal products exhibiting higher average selling prices have been outgrowing other product groups). In terms of volumes, the market ----- observed a strong acceleration of demand tied primarily to demographic vectors and new regulations (notably in France with 100% Santé). Going forward, we expect the optical products market to continue to grow in Spain and France on the back of the aforementioned dynamics (positive demographic, social and economic drivers as well as favorable regulatory frameworks).

Between 2016 and 2023, the hearing aid market in France grew at a rate of 9.3% per year driven, especially, by a step increase in 2021 (61.0% growth in value over 2020 and 2021) following the implementation of the 100% Santé regulation, which allowed more affordable prices and wider access to hearing aid equipment (the high price of equipment long constituted a significant obstacle to hearingimpaired populations). The 100% Santé effect was largely volume driven (85.0% growth in volume of devices sold over 2020 and 2021) as average prices were lowered (20.0% decrease in price over 2020 and 2021), also reflecting the sizeable demand historically contained by the high prices of hearing aid devices, as shown in the graph below (according to Xerfi and DREES). The health authorities have taken significant measures, not only by substantially increasing coverage of expenses (with Social Security greatly increasing reimbursements, far surpassing those in optics) but also through their 100% _Santé communication campaign. This effort addresses public health concerns related to hearing loss_ and promotes the entirely free offer available to the public. _Sources: Xerfi, DREES « Comptes de la santé 2022 »._ Further, in addition to the _100% Santé impact, the hearing aid market is, similar to optical products, underpinned by resilient drivers and stable growth in line with the non-discretionary, healthcare-related nature of the product. Going forward, we expect the hearing aid market to continue to grow on the back of continuous volume growth, driven by demography (as the population at large continues to grow and grow older), regulatory backdrops (especially in France where strong demand is continuously expected following _100% Santé, which made hearing aids more affordable) and shorter renewal cycles (with _100% Santé allowing customers to renew their hearing aid products every four years) more than_ offsetting structurally decreasing average selling prices. Additionally, when it comes time to replace devices, we believe that hearing aid wearers will likely opt for higher quality and more expensive devices. The below graph shows the evolution of the hearing aid markets from 2016 to 2024 in both France and Spain: ----- _Sources: Xerfi and Sra.Modne._

_Players’ Archetypes and footprint_ With retail networks composed of a large number of small independent players, competition is primarily local and small. A limited number of players compete on a national or regional scale, some of which use new business models (named “challengers”, such as pure online players or low-cost chains). Few, however, benefit from a transnational scale like ALAIN AFFLELOU which is a market player in different geographies. _Source: Xerfi._ The market is segmented between (i) retail optical chains, (ii) marketing groups, (iii) independent retailers and members of buying groups and, in France, (iv) mutualists (mutuelles): _Retail chains include groups of five or more stores with an operating model based on a franchise model,_ a fully-owned model (i.e. “integrated networks”) or a combination of both. ALAIN AFFLELOU falls in this ----- category (see “Business”) amongst peers like GrandVision in France (operating the Grand Optical, Générale d’Optique and Solaris banners in France). _Marketing groups (also referred as “cooperatives”) regroup independent opticians under a single_ banner. They started with a goal to pool resources, especially for their purchases, and progressively shared more services (such as marketing), while keeping a significant level of autonomy, compared to franchise businesses. Store owners pay a contribution fee in order to benefit from pooled resources and services, with each owning equity capital and involved in the decision-making process of the group. Marketing groups refer to brands like Optic 2000, Krys and Atol in France. _Independent retailers (or members of buying groups) operate their own stores and brands, bearing all_ related risks. These independent owners may join buying groups to benefit from better purchasing conditions, but generally do not benefit from collective benefits of retail chains or marketing groups. Mutualists consist of insurance-owned or related groups, a model only existing in France. In the past, people with certain insurance policies (e.g. school teachers) could buy optical products at a muchreduced price, fully reimbursed by health insurance companies, paving the way for nation-wide chains such as Les Opticiens Mutualistes (recently renamed Ecouter Voir). Following a regulatory change in 2014, these groups no longer benefit from a protective statute and fully operate like other retail chains open to every customer, although still linked to insurance companies with preferred tariffs and prices for members. In addition, so-called challengers are progressively emerging with pharmacist groups and new players, usually start-ups, based on digital-only models (especially for products like contact lenses that are automatically renewed without the need to see or test products) or disruptive retail models (faster processing times, price competitiveness, specific clientele targeted, etc.). In the latter case, a number of these disruptive players are actively owned by historical groups (for instance ALAIN AFFLELOU owns Malentille.com, a digital-only company). _Market Share_ The Spanish and French markets for optical products are fragmented in value, with main participants in each market accounting for a maximum of 13.0% (France) and 19.0% (Spain) of market share (according to Xerfi). Independent retailers have especially experienced the steepest market share losses in recent years 3.0% market share decline since 2015 in France (according to Advancy) due to increasing competitive pressure from optical groups in a market generally trending towards more consolidation and verticalization (i.e., integration of some suppliers such as with the acquisition by Essilor-Luxottica of GrandVision). As this trend continues, competitive advantages from larger distributors like ALAIN AFFLELOU are expected to continue to grow on the back of greater purchasing power, better talent management and economies of scale while independent players in particular – representing the largest share of stores but a limited market share in value – are expected to continue to be absorbed. As of 2023, ALAIN AFFLELOU was the largest retail chain group and third largest optical group in France with a 9% market share, behind Optic 2000 (12% market share), Krys (13% market share) (according to Xerfi). In Spain, ALAIN AFFLELOU was the fifth largest optical player with a 7.0% market share, behind Multiopticas (19.0% market share), General Optica (12% market share), Opticalia (10.0% market share) and Optica & Audiologia Universitaria (8% market share). The graphs below shows our market share compared to other market players in France and Spain. ----- _Source: Xerfi._ As shown below, on the back of continuous outperformance compared to equivalent large peers, ALAIN AFFLELOU has continued to gain share since 2019 (0.5% gain in market share from 2019-2021) according to Advancy, Xerfi and Company information. ALAIN AFFLELOU / ALAIN AFFLELOU / _Source: Xerfi._

In much the same way as for optical products, the competitive landscape is segmented between small independent players, holding approximately 56.0% market share in France (according to Xerfi), and larger regional and national players, regrouped into either optical chains with dual activity (like ALAIN AFFLELOU) or pure hearing aid players (like Amplifon), in each case present in the same archetypes as for the optical products market (i.e., retail chains, mutualists, independent retailers or marketing groups). While there are many regional and national players, only a handful have a multi-country approach like ALAIN AFFLELOU. Dual activity (i.e. hearing and optical) amongst optical groups has been spreading and accelerating since 2019 with an increasing number of optical groups integrating audio corners into their networks with the implementation of the 100% Santé reform in France; however, the development of those have lagged frontrunners like ALAIN AFFLELOU, Krys, Acuitis and Optic 2000 who have seized the full benefit / market uptick earlier than the implementation of this reform, having started a dual activity early on. ALAIN AFFLELOU / ----- _Market Share_ In France and Spain, despite continuous market penetration by optical groups, the market remains dominated by pure hearing aids players such as Amplifon or Audika. We believe the largest player in this market to be Amplifon, with a 13% market share in France compared to 3.0% for ALAIN AFFLELOU (according to Xerfi). In Spain, ALAIN AFFLELOU currently holds an approximately 2.0% market share, after a rapid growth in the two past years, according to Company information. -----

Founded by Mr. Alain Afflelou in Bordeaux in 1972, we are a leading optical product and hearing aid franchisor in Europe. We operate the largest French optical product franchise network in terms of both revenue and number of stores in France. ALAIN AFFLELOU is the third-largest optical business overall, with a 9.0% market share in 2023 (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales) in a fragmented market that has historically included many independent retailers (according to Xerfi). In addition to our historical French market, we have a large and well-developed network in Spain, our second core domestic market, where we had 368 stores as of April 30, 2024. We operated the largest optical product franchise network in Spain (in terms of number of stores) and were the fifth largest optical retail chain, with a 7.0% market share in 2023 (in terms of revenue, including VAT and excluding online sales) (according to Xerfi). As of July 31, 2023, France, Spain and Other countries, our three geographic segments, represented 64.0%, 26.0% and 10.0%, respectively, of our total number of stores. The retail sale of optical products and hearing aids represented 92.8% and 7.2%, respectively, of our network sales for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. Building on our significant market share in our core geographic markets, France and Spain, we have grown our ALAIN AFFLELOU total store count to 1,434 stores as of April 30, 2024 compared to 1,397 as of April 30, 2023. In the past eleven years, we have grown our market share and maintained a leadership position in our key markets. Our growth is in part the result of market growth at a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 2.7% and 2.4% in France and Spain, respectively, from calendar years 2019 to 2023 (according to GfK), as well as the performance of the ALAIN AFFLELOU brand itself. Our intensive and long-term marketing and advertising efforts and campaigns (including our partnerships with key brand ambassadors) have also contributed to the success and power of our brand. In our two main secondary markets, Belgium and Switzerland, network sales for ALAIN AFFLELOU grew at a CAGR of 2.0% and 8.7%, respectively, from calendar years 2019 to 2023. We have been strategically adapting our store perimeter in recent years to increase profitability. We rely on our strong brand and large network of franchisees. Each additional store that we open allows us to benefit from economies of scale by spreading our fixed costs over a broader base of stores and sales potential. Such fixed costs include mainly the support costs of the network management, personnel costs and, among other things, administrative fees and structural costs, warehousing and inventory management costs, as well advertising and marketing costs relating to the promotion of our brand (which we believe will in turn benefit a larger number of stores and generate a greater volume of sales). The essential, health-care nature of our products makes them largely non-discretionary purchases that may, at best, be sometimes delayed. We estimate that approximately 96.0% of our products are purchased by our customers as a result of a prescription or a medical need, namely: prescription glasses (82.0%), hearing aids (8.0%), contact lenses (6.0%). For example, at ALAIN AFFLELOU in France and Spain under both optical and hearing aids, for the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, 95.7% of network sales were generated by sales of glasses or hearing aids that are generally purchased with a prescription. According to 2024 data from Gallileo, 85.0% of customers indicated their reason for purchasing new glasses was the result of a medical need compared to 15.0% who indicated it was based on personal, non-health-related preferences. These dynamics create resilience and predictability in our sales as customers replace prescription products in regular and fairly short intervals (especially in countries where we benefit from a favorable regulatory framework whereby the majority of prescription products are reimbursed by social security and healthcare insurance providers, as is the case in France, our main market). In addition, these factors drive stable replacement cycles. For example, in France, the average replacement cycle from 2015 to 2021 was estimated to be 2.8 years, which replacement cycle remained stable for the last ten years according to a report prepared by Advancy in 2022. In Spain, the average replacement cycle from 2015 to 2021 was estimated to be 4.2 years, according to the same report. The rest of our sales result from discretionary purchases, such as sunglasses and optical and hearing aid accessories. Even in times of economic difficulty or pandemics, customers continue to buy and order glasses while our stores (which are classified as “essential” businesses, reflecting the healthcare-nature of the products we sell) remain open. Alternatively, ----- customers may defer their purchase for only a short period of time. As a demonstration of this effect, after COVID-19 confinement periods, we observed a rebound in sales, which generally outperformed the same period in prior years, as customers caught up on overdue purchases for prescription glasses, lenses and hearing aids. We operate in highly attractive markets that are differentiated from traditional retail markets due to the largely non-discretionary and healthcare-related nature of optical and hearing aid expenses and a supportive healthcare reimbursement system in France. We believe that both the optical product and hearing aid markets are supported by positive structural drivers, including demographic trends, changing lifestyles, technological innovations, product penetration dynamics and value-adding product add-ons. In addition, our signature products are a key value differentiator, generating customer interest and good margins for us and our franchisees. The success of our franchisee-centered business model is demonstrated by the over-performance of our franchisees compared to the wider market: average revenue per store for ALAIN AFFLELOU in France for the 2021 calendar year was €0.9 million (including VAT), which is approximately 1.5 times the retail market average (and approximately 3.3 times the independent and smaller marketing group retailer store in 2021), and our average revenue per store in Spain for the calendar year ended 2019 was €0.4 million, which was approximately 2.1 times the retail market average in that year (and approximately 4.8 times the independent and smaller market group retailer store average in 2019), demonstrating the added value we offer to current and potential franchisees. Our strategy is based on strong branding, exclusive products, multi-possession, payment solutions and positive customer experience, and a multi-offer approach that reaches a variety of price points and target customers. ALAIN AFFLELOU offers a wide range of optical and hearing aid products, including our exclusive products, which consist of (i) signature label frames and sunglasses bearing the “Afflelou” signature; (ii) frames and sunglasses under exclusive licenses; and (iii) other exclusive brands and third-party names. We connect with and understand consumers in our markets through our communications and marketing efforts, which have created a powerful and enduring brand image, as evidenced by our high brand awareness with customers in our main markets. Among optical retailers, we ranked first in terms of spontaneous and assisted awareness in France, second in terms of spontaneous awareness in Spain and first in assisted awareness in Wallonia (Belgium) and ranked second in assisted brand awareness among hearing aid retailers, according to various market studies conducted in 2018 and 2019. We also connect with consumers via our online presence. We began developing our online presence in 2012 and have progressively been incorporating our online initiatives under a unified digital umbrella. Currently we maintain websites in the languages of the principal countries where we operate. Additionally, in September 2016, we acquired two online pure players, Happyview.fr and Malentille.com. We have incorporated the activities of Happyview.fr into our French Afflelou website. Malentille.com continues to serve customers on its own platform with back-end integration with the Group’s online activities. Our principal activity is to act as a franchisor, licensing the use of our brand to franchisees and providing them with the right to trade under our brand and implement our value proposition through our commercial offers. Our directly-owned stores support our principal franchisor activity by (i) serving as flagship locations in and around Paris and other key strategic locations and large urban areas; (ii) helping to test new concepts; (iii) facilitating store network management; and (iv) generating high purchase volumes, which facilitates our negotiations with suppliers. Our services as a franchisor are aimed at helping franchisees grow their sales by fostering a strong brand image, driving customers to our stores through the design and promotion of our commercial offers and facilitating franchisee operations via a number of support services. Our scale and expertise yield tangible benefits to our franchisees, allowing us to offer (i) commercial support and innovation through new commercial offers and through high-impact national and local communication campaigns that ----- create high brand awareness; (ii) access to central listing and purchasing unit services that lower costs for our franchisees; (iii) dedicated services that enhance store attractiveness, including assistance with location selection and store design; (iv) training programs designed to enhance sales performance; and (v) other general support functions, including legal, human resources and recruiting assistance, as well as assistance with joining care networks in France. Our franchise model also offers tangible benefits to our suppliers by giving them access to our global network of stores. We also provide suppliers with distribution services, including a central listing and payment unit that allows suppliers to list and offer their products to our franchisees, while offering the benefit of having a single counterparty for commercial negotiations and payments. We also support suppliers by actively promoting their innovative products to our franchisees, as well as through sales in our directly-owned stores. Our franchise model combines: (i) revenue based on network sales of our franchisees (27.4% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023), (ii) revenue based on purchases (42.2% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023) and (iii) revenue generated by sales to end-customers in our directly-owned stores and through our websites (30.4% of our revenue in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023). Revenue based on network sales includes in particular: entry fees, franchise fees and communication fees, as well as other fees charged for services that we provide to our franchisees. Revenue based on purchases includes in particular: trading as well as central listing and payment unit (which are charged to our listed suppliers) and licensing fees and revenue from sales of our exclusive products. Revenue generated by our directly-owned stores mainly includes sales made directly to endcustomers in those directly-owned stores, as well as through our websites. This model not only provides us with revenue diversification but also increases our Adjusted EBITDA by increasing our network sales at limited fixed costs when opening new franchisee stores. This results in greater economies of scale and improved operating leverage and profitability. Our main costs are related to the supply and production of products that we sell under our own brands or for which we have a license. For our exclusive frames, Okia, a company based in China, has long been our favored intermediary. Okia is not a manufacturer but sources its products from a network of independent factories in Asia and allows the Group to benefit from optimal production conditions through this unique commercial relationship.

_Overview_ Our franchisees are independent entrepreneurs who have entered into franchise agreements with us to operate one or several optical and/or hearing aid points of sale. By partnering with us, our franchisees gain access to our proven franchise model, providing them with (i) greater access to customers through increased brand awareness, our marketing and communication strategy and attractive and affordable offers, (ii) access to our exclusive Afflelou-branded products, (iii) negotiated terms with a large number of listed suppliers in our central listing structure, and additional negotiated terms with certain listed suppliers through our central purchasing unit and (iv) support services throughout the lifecycle of the franchise, including store design and merchandising, financing and sales force support and recruiting. _Our franchise agreements_ The terms and conditions of our franchise agreements define the reciprocal roles and obligations of us and our franchisees and reflect the particular requirements of each of our brands, which are generally comparable across our network, as well as the different jurisdictions in which we operate. Likewise, levels of remuneration paid to us from franchisees vary from country to country. Franchise agreements in our network generally have an initial three-year term and are automatically renewed two years in advance for an additional one-year period, unless the contract is terminated during its initial period or during each such additional period, for a maximum period of ten years. As a result of the renewal conditions of our franchise agreements, we generally have visibility of approximately two years on the evolution of our franchise partnerships. Franchisees are granted exclusivity in a certain territory with respect to where they are operating, and in return, they are subject to standard non-compete provisions. In order to protect the integrity of the ALAIN AFFLELOU network, we only operate with franchisees who are exclusively involved in the optical and hearing aid businesses in our network (other than limited arrangements with certain independent stores). In addition, franchisees are generally prohibited from carrying out a franchise activity with any other group or franchise or distribution network during a period of one year from the date of the end of the franchise agreement. We receive a one-time entry fee per store. Additionally, pursuant to our standard franchise agreement, franchisees pay a monthly standard franchise fee of 4.15% of their network sales (excluding VAT) in France and 4.23% of their network sales (excluding VAT) in Spain. The royalty fee is our fee for the award of a non-exclusive license to use our brand and trademarks according to the terms of the franchise agreement, as well as the provision of various other franchisor services, in particular the know-how that we provide to the franchisee during the course of the agreement. See “—Services that _we provide as franchisor” for a description of the services we provide to franchisees._ Additionally, as franchisor, we provide communications and marketing services as further described under “—Advertising and communications to build strong brand awareness”, for which the franchisees compensate us. For European franchisees, the communications budget for each country is presented by management and approved at the annual meeting of the relevant CNF (as defined in “—Franchisee _representation”) and is generally the same proportion of sales for any franchisee with no negotiation_ except for franchisees outside of metropolitan areas. For non-European franchisees, the compensation for these services is set in the franchise agreement and varies in amount depending on the market and our local communications strategy. For example, communication fees are currently set at 8.76% of a franchisee’s network sales for the ALAIN AFFLELOU optical business in France (excluding VAT) and ----- 8.34% of a franchisee’s network sales for the ALAIN AFFLELOU optical business in Spain (excluding VAT). We may terminate a franchise agreement in a number of circumstances, in particular in cases of a material failure by the franchisee to observe our commercial policy or where a franchisee closes its store or is unable to maintain or renew the relevant lease, fails to make payments required under the agreement or becomes insolvent. Additionally, we may terminate the contract upon the death or incapacity of the franchisee or the loss of his or her license as an optician or audio prosthetist (as applicable), or in certain other events, including the violation of the non-compete provision. The franchisee may also terminate a franchise agreement without cause at the end of the initial three-year period or during its extension periods, by notifying the franchisor within two calendar years (whether successive or not), in which case the agreement would terminate at the start of the calendar year that immediately follows the year in which the second notice was given. If a franchise agreement is terminated due to a franchisee failing to meet its contractual obligations or at the franchisee’s request before the end of the current contractual period, the contract provides that we retain the right to receive our annual royalties and communication fees provided for under the agreement until the end of the initial duration of the franchise agreement. In addition, franchisees are obligated to return our signage upon termination, in order to avoid any confusion for end-customers. The termination of a franchise agreement remains rare and we continue to grow our franchisee network given we believe our franchise model is mutually beneficial to the franchisee and franchisor. As franchisor and in accordance with our obligations under the franchise agreement, we have the following obligations: - providing our franchisees the know-how, expertise and training necessary to operate their business; - allowing franchisees to use our brands and merchandizing as well as allowing them to use our central listing and purchasing unit and our commercial offers; and - developing and implementing publicity campaigns and communications at our level. As franchisee and in accordance with its obligations under the franchise agreement, the franchisee must in particular respect the following obligations: - paying ongoing royalties as indicated above; - purchasing their products exclusively from suppliers listed by our central listing and payment unit; - complying with certain requirements in terms of merchandizing and store layout, so that brand identity is aligned and the same store concept is used throughout our networks; - implementing our commercial strategy and promoting our commercial offers; - contributing to communications and advertising expenses and submitting any local advertising initiative for our approval; - purchasing samples of and displaying our branded products in their stores; - reporting sales levels on a monthly basis (franchisees may also report other performance indicators, such as sales by product and total number of products sold); - providing us with a copy of their annual accounts; - granting us a right of first refusal in the event that they seek to sell their business or retire; ----- - adhering to a non-compete clause prohibiting affiliation with a competing network, which typically extends for one year after the termination of the franchise agreement; - adhering to certain confidentiality provisions; and - following the termination of the franchise agreement, ensuring that all manner of trade goods and fixtures pertaining to our brands, including our store concept, furniture, display shelves and signage, are removed from the store. _Franchisee representation_ Our relations with our franchisees are mainly structured around national franchisee commissions (each, a “CNF”) which we have set up in each of the European countries in which we carry out our activities. The CNFs are responsible for (i) collectively representing the franchisees in their relationship with us; (ii) centralizing, simplifying and organizing communications with the franchisor; and (iii) approving certain decisions, such as our marketing plan, which is submitted annually for the approval of the relevant CNF. In France, the optical CNF is composed of 15 members for a term of three years, representing a total population of 392 franchisees, and the CNF for hearing aids franchisees is composed of seven members for a term of three years, representing a total population of approximately ten franchisees. In Spain, the CNF is composed of eleven members, representing a total population of 177 franchisees. See also “Regulation” for a summary of the regulatory framework that applies to our relationship with franchisees. _Franchisee profile_ We ask our franchisees to deliver the customer service and purchasing experience that customers expect from ALAIN AFFLELOU. Forming close, successful partnerships with franchisees based on mutual commercial success is an essential component of our business model. The following presents a profile of our franchisees. _Optical_ On average, as of July 31, 2023, ALAIN AFFLELOU franchisees operated 1.9 optical stores in France, 1.5 optical stores in Spain, and 1.6, 1.1 and 2.5 optical stores in each of Belgium, Portugal and Switzerland. In certain non-European markets, the profiles of our franchisees may differ from those common in Europe, and the Group may enter into relationships with optical retailers managing a few ALAIN AFFLELOU, and acting as master-franchisee. The average sales (including VAT) per ALAIN AFFLELOU store in calendar year 2023 was €872,000 in France (excluding centers only operating hearing aids) and €398,000 in Spain and €300,000 for hearing aid centers in France compared to the market average of optical stores of approximately €550,000 in France in 2021 and €190,000 in Spain in 2021. However, average revenue (including VAT and excluding online sales) for independent retailers was €250,000 in France in 2021 and €83,000 in Spain in 2018. We believe the out performance of stores in our network is mainly the result of: (i) the quality of service that our franchisees provide to customers; (ii) the strong recognition of the ALAIN AFFLELOU brand; and (iii) the services that we provide to franchisees which support and assist them in their operations. For further information about our competitive position in the geographies where we compete, see “Industry”. Our ten largest franchisees (across our network and jurisdictions) own and operate an average of ten stores, representing 8.3% of network sales in the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023. The biggest one operated 15 stores (excluding corners) as of July 31, 2023. Thus, we believe that we are not dependent on any one franchisee. In the fiscal year ended July 31, 2023, 20 new franchisees representing 21 stores, joined ALAIN AFFLELOU in France, entering our network either through openings or purchases of existing stores from franchisees. ----- _Hearing aids_ As of July 31, 2023, our 91 hearing aid franchisees in France operated an average of 4.1 points of sale, distributed between 1.9 centers (a store dedicated to hearing aids) and 3.2 corners inside optical stores. In Spain, our hearing aid franchisees operated on average 2.3 points of sale, distributed between 1.0 center (a store dedicated to hearing aids) and 1.3 corners inside optical stores. For more information regarding our network and our main geographies, see “—Distribution channels”.

Subsubsection Title: Services that we provide as franchisor
Subsubsection Text: As franchisor, we provide our franchisees, both before the opening of their store and throughout the course of their operations, advice and support services. Our services as franchisor, the relationships formed with franchisees and the interaction between us, our franchisees and end-customers are intended to increase franchisees’ sales. The following section describes the characteristics of our brand, which is regularly reviewed, either through customer surveys performed by various institutions in France and Spain for the whole sector and studies that we commissioned as well as a brief description of the know-how that we provide our franchisees. _Financing solutions for franchisees_ As part of our franchisor role, we offer different financing solutions for developing franchisees’ activities: - _New store openings. Opening an optical or hearing aid store requires capital. In an effort to attract a new generation of franchisees and accelerate the transition of certain of our directly-owned stores into franchised stores, we piloted a financial support program. This program, called “Project Adelante” (“PA”), began in Spain in 2013 and was extended to France in 2016. As of July 31, 2023, approximately 140 of our stores in Spain and France have benefitted from our PA program, and some of these have already reimbursed us. The aim of the program is to help qualified opticians with strong entrepreneurial ambitions transition into successful franchisees. Those who are selected to participate in the PA program are provided training in various fields such as management and finance. In Spain, we provide financial support to these opticians by guaranteeing bank loans obtained from partner banks, which facilitates opticians’ access to financing, which is necessary at the start of their franchisee business. In France, we help finance the new franchisee by purchasing convertible bonds issued by the new franchise company, helping it obtain the equity cushion it needs to qualify for bank financing. As part of the PA program, potential and/or future franchisees can be hired by us as managers of directly-owned stores in order to increase the potential and/or future franchisee’s knowledge and experience, before taking over a franchise store. - _Working capital financing. We have negotiated financial support for our franchisees with consumer finance lender Cofidis, our partner with our NextYear financing solutions to end customers. As a complement to the partnership with us on credit consuming activity, Cofidis makes available a working capital advance to our franchisees, for which we pay the interest, to allow them to pay for signature label eyewear products put on display one year after purchase. In addition, we have put in place several framework agreements with partner banks to finance refurbishment, store design or working capital needs. These agreements allow our franchisees to access external financing at preferential conditions compared to those they would receive from their usual partners and be subject to less stringent requirements as a result of our support. These agreements can also be used for temporary needs. For instance, more than 400 of our franchisees benefitted from a €20,000 loan in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic. - _Assistance relating to relationships with banks and other service providers. In addition to advising and supporting our franchisees, we have selected a number of partner banks, including BNP Paribas, Société Générale-Crédit du Nord and CM-CIC, and service providers (such as accounting networks, including KPMG, Fiducial and In Extenso), that are able to service our franchisee network, and that have a close relationship with, and knowledge of, our network, in order to facilitate franchisees’ financial management. ----- - _Other arrangements. As part of our franchisee management approach, we can, from time to time, offer direct support to our franchisees, either through individual arrangements with franchisees experiencing cash or working capital needs or through postponements of franchisee payments. For example, at the beginning of the pandemic, the Group took various measures to support the financial health of the store network, including by reducing monthly instalments in March, April and May 2020 (for a total amount of more than €30.0 million) and through loans granted by banks and guaranteed by the Group (for a total approximate amount of €15.0 million, of which approximately 450 loans of €20,000 were granted by our partner Cofidis in the NextYear offer under the framework agreements described above). Where we offer payment deferrals, the network team, together with the financial and the legal departments, creates reimbursement plans and franchisees enter into agreements that govern and set out their commitments and related guarantees. Thanks to strong sales recovery and the loans described above, there were no outstanding amounts on deferred payments of our franchisees as of July 31, 2023. _Advertising and communications to build strong brand awareness_ Since our founding, we have developed significant know-how in terms of advertising and communications. Our communications strategy focuses on promoting the reputation of our brands, as well as educating customers about our commercial offers and new products bearing our own brands. Our commercial offers are relayed by television, our websites and apps, text message, e-mail, social media, billboards, radio and print, through marketing campaigns or sponsorship opportunities and by in-store signage. Our multimedia advertising campaigns and communications strategy are intended to be memorable, resonate with customers and inspire confidence in our opticians and audio prosthetists, while informing customers of our commercial offers. These campaigns and communications also drive footfall to our stores. Our communications efforts are carefully monitored with the assistance of advertising agencies, notably through the analysis of our gross advertising expenses compared to our competitors in our main geographies and performance of our “share of voice” in various media. We regularly assess our brand awareness in countries in which we have a significant market share, using market studies we commission, such as OpinionWay for France, Belgium and Switzerland and Punto de Fuga for Spain. We use these studies to better follow the results of our commercial offers and communication campaigns. We also look at third-party consumer surveys (not conducted at our request), which we regularly purchase from various companies specialized in our markets, such as Arcane and Gallileo in France. As shown below, ALAIN AFFLELOU ranks number one, either in spontaneous or assisted awareness in France, as pointed out by several and periodic customer survey studies, summarized below.

Our principal activity is acting as a franchisor, allowing our franchisees to trade optical and hearing aid products under our brands. Pursuant to the terms of the franchise agreements that we enter into with each of our franchisees, we authorize our franchisees to use our brands and sell our owned branded products, grant them the right to distribute optical products and/or hearing aids under the ALAIN AFFLELOU brand, allow them to use our commercial offerings and provide them with a variety of tools, services and know-how. We encourage our franchisees to deploy our innovative commercial offers through our overall communication strategy, including publicity and communication campaigns to promote our brands and drive traffic to their stores. Our communication strategy showcases the strength of the ALAIN AFFLELOU brand through a diverse array of initiatives, with a primary focus on nationwide outreach bolstered by digital tools, including SMS and email campaigns. In addition to our communication campaigns, we organize the overall communication of our brand on behalf of our franchisees. The best practices that we develop in our directly-owned stores are shared with our franchisees and serve as a benchmark for the standard maintained throughout our entire network. We have also put in place a comprehensive supply, purchase and logistics system for our franchisees. Additionally, we sell optical products that bear the “AFFLELOU” signature label, which are distributed to franchisees as a means to extend their product range. The services that we offer our franchisees as franchisor aim to develop, support and foster the business of our franchisees. We believe that the services we offer to our franchisees allow them to develop their business, increase their performance and offer consumers a better shopping experience while continually reinforcing the image of our brand. This role also allows us to increase footfall to stores and assist in franchisee recruitment. The following ----- sections present an overview of our relationship with our franchisees and describe the various services that we provide to them.

The majority of our stores in Belgium are located in this region. In Switzerland, OpinionWay ranked ALAIN AFFLELOU fourth in both assisted and spontaneous brand awareness, with 82% assisted awareness, in a survey conducted in March 2021, among a representative sample of the French speaking population. Finally, as shown below, ALAIN AFFLELOU Acousticien in France ranks as a leader among hearing aid specialists in France, either in spontaneous or assisted awareness.

Subsubsection Text: Top of mind spontaneous awareness (ranking # and % of awareness) .................... Sept. 2020 - #2 – 31% 2013 - #2 – 16% Feb. 2023 - #2 – 34% 2016 - #2 – 24% 2019 - #2 – 36% (among potential customers) Assisted awareness (ranking # and % of awareness) ....................................................
