##### Rental obligations in respect of administrative leases for stores operated by the Group are now recognized in the balance sheet pursuant to IFRS 16. Sundry guarantees to third parties correspond mainly to rental obligations that the Group has kept with some lessors on stores sold, in exchange for similar commitments received in the Group’s favour, from franchisee buyers. These guarantees also include commitments to purchase stores from three franchisees (compared with two franchisees as of 31 July 2020). Bonds and bank guarantees given cover liabilities to banks financing franchisees, either as part of acquisitions or openings of outlets or assistance with funding refurbishments or working capital. Secured loans are part of the overall budgets. The Group is involved in these transactions in its capacity as guarantor to these banks of the financing they provide to franchisees in the proportion of 100% of each application for financing, with in certain cases a maximum portion of the overall package. Commitments received related to the central payment structure consist mainly of pledges and guarantees made by the franchisees on schedules or agreements covering the repayment of the debts of the central payment structure. In addition, the Group benefits from commitments received as part of the relationship with franchisees. Under franchise agreements, franchisees are encouraged to make personal guarantees in favour of the Group for the obligations and liabilities they incur to the Group’s central payment structure. These guarantees are generally prorated at 30% of annual net revenue in France and Spain. However, only guarantees and sureties related to franchisees’ specific debts (agreements, staggered payments, vendor loans) are shown in the table of commitments received. Dependence of the Group on patents, licences and supply contracts The Group is not significantly dependent on patents, licenses or supply contracts. 6.6.3. Notifications, lawsuits and disputes Companies belonging to the Group may become involved in lawsuits or litigation in the normal course of their business, including disputes with tax, social security or customs authorities. Notification of VAT deductibility On 8 December 2017, the Group received a notification from the tax authorities following an audit of VAT deducted by Optical Finance in the years 2014 to 2016. Adjustments notified by the tax authorities amounted to €1.5 million. Following receipt of the tax authorities’ assessment on 16 August 2018, the group decided to pay the sum corresponding to the principal adjustment of €966 thousand. Nevertheless, the Group referred the matter to the Paris administrative tribunal, considering the authorities’ position to be unfounded. The Group also called the vendor warranties issued by the vendor shareholders on its acquisition of Optical Finance, which are capped at €1 million. Investigation by the French Competition Authority On 27 May 2015, the French Competition Authority notified Alain Afflelou Franchiseur of grievances, accusing it of “having colluded with providers of eye- and sunglass frames, from 2003 at the latest and until 2009, to fix retail prices and to impede the fixing of prices through free competition in violation of the provisions of Article L.420-1 of the French Commercial Code and Article 101 paragraph 1 of the TFEU”. The French Competition Authority issued a decision on the vertical agreement grievances on 24 February 2017. It decided to refer the issue back for further investigations. On 19 April 2019, Alain Afflelou Franchiseur received notification of additional grievances in which no grievance was filed against it. No response was therefore given to this notification. On 2 March 2020, Alain Afflelou Franchiseur received the additional report from the French Competition Authority. Even though Alain Afflelou Franchiseur is still not concerned by the additional grievances, it issued a response to the Competition Authority on certain procedural arguments of interest to it. Under the terms of its decision 21-D-20 of 22 July 2021 relating to practices implemented in the eyewear and eyeglass frames sector, the French Competition Authority definitively closed this dispute, without any finding against the AFFLELOU Group. Deductibility of interest expense on convertible bonds A tax adjustment notice was served in December 2018 in respect of income tax for the years ended 31 July 2013, 2014 and 2015. It concerned the deductibility of the 14% interest expense on the convertible bonds issued in July 2012 as part of the Group’s acquisition by LBO, in an amount of approximately €203 million. The French tax authorities reject the deductibility of the interest on these convertible bonds. The Group, on the basis of the analysis carried out by our legal and tax advisors, contested the proposed adjustment in a response sent to the French tax authorities in February 2019. However, the Group received an audit notice on 7 April 2021 concerning fiscal years 2016 to 2020. Since then, discussions have taken place with the tax authorities, resulting in the acceptance of an agreement with them. The comprehensive settlement signed with the tax authorities, in addition to definitively closing the dispute and eliminating the potential risk of legal action for abuse of rights, generated a €31 million reduction in deferred tax assets (out of total deferred tax assets in respect of tax loss carryforwards of €65.8 million as of 31 July 2020) without any tax payment or penalty. ----- ##### Other tax disputes involving corporate income tax Following a tax audit launched in 2015 covering the period from 1 August 2009 to 31 July 2012, the French tax authorities issued an initial tax reassessment notice primarily reassessing the price at which Alain Afflelou Franchiseur sold certain loss-making subsidiaries in 2010, claiming that the sale price would have had to be higher for it to be considered at arm’s length. The company and its legal and tax advisors believe that there are strong arguments to challenge the position of the French tax authorities. If, however, the arguments of the tax authorities were to prevail, the potential amount of the adjustment would be €21 million on the tax base. Verification of supplier payment terms On 21 September 2020, DIRECCTE initiated an inspection in connection with the commitment made by Alain Afflelou Franchiseur to comply with the legal payment terms formulated at the time of its application for a government-guaranteed loan. On 2 March 2021, the company submitted its comments on the payment terms monitored by DIRECCTE for the period from 1 June 2020 to 31 August 2020 and produced all documents in support of these observations. After a hearing on 2 March 2021, DIRECCTE drew up a report of the statement and took copies of the documents. At this stage, DIRECCTE has not followed up on this hearing. 6.7. Related parties 6.7.1. Short-term benefits The compensation of the various corporate officers of the Board of Directors paid and recorded by the Group, including employment contracts, corporate office agreements and executive functions, amounted to €2,450 thousand in fiscal 2021 and €515 thousand in fiscal 2020. The amount of this compensation also includes severance, termination or dismissal payments. 6.7.2.2. Long-term benefits In addition to the benefits related to the defined benefit pension plan, described in 6.2.14, the Company has taken out a GSC (“garantie sociale des dirigeants et chefs d’entreprise”) insurance policy for the Chairman providing for payment covering 70% of his net compensation (the “GSC”) for a period of eighteen (18) months. GSC contributions constitute a benefit in kind subject to social security contributions and income tax. It is also provided that in the event of termination of the Chairman’s term of office by the Board of Directors or the shareholders of the Company during the first 12 months of his term of office, the Chairman will be entitled to receive 70% of his fixed monthly compensation, paid monthly by the Company for a period of 18 months, provided that he is registered as unemployed with Pôle Emploi. If the Chairman’s term of office is terminated by the Board of Directors or the shareholders of the Company between the 13th and 18th month of his term of office, the Chairman will be entitled, as from the 13th month following the date of termination, to receive 70% of his monthly fixed compensation, paid monthly by the Company for a period of six months, provided that he is registered as unemployed with Pôle Emploi. ----- ##### 6.8.
